docs.text: Pointr Developer Portal ¶ The home of Deep Location® Welcome to the Pointr SDK Documents portal Read on to find out more about our Indoor Positioning, Augmented Reality Navigation, Location Based Messaging, Indoor Analytics, Indoor Tracking and other services Here to help, here to disrupt ¶ What you’ll find here: guides refs support and FAQs demos updates news use cases other resources The Leading AI/AR Platform For Smart Indoors ¶ Our SDK provides a powerful platform for creating fully-customisable, high-performance Indoor Positioning using industry standards and world class expertise Cutting edge Location technology ¶ We're trusted because we’re so good ¶ Now is the time to bring flexibility and strength to any Indoor Experience Feature List: The most accurate “Blue Dot” Effortless content management; and, Powerful, dynamic Pathfinding managed by Pointr Cloud Quick start with our Sample App Offline operation and automatic content syncing Fresh, agile mapping, management and POI marking Detailed reporting and simulation tools Rapidly custimisable components View some awesome demos! ¶ it’s about time for some context ¶ Boasting an impressive compatibility rating as well as drop-in starter Samples, our Developer Starter Kit is where to go when you want to start experimenting with Indoor experiences. Get started today and make things happen! ¶ Android Quickstart iOS Quickstart Pointr Cloud

docs.text: Get Started With Pointr Cloud ¶ Here you can find information about logging in, data analytics functions, map management, notification management, and settings and configurations, and other useful information. Disclaimer All maps and data shown in this document are for demonstration purposes only and not based on factual data. The images shown may differ in the document and on your screen depending on the user permissions and updates in Pointr Cloud. Email support in order to give feedback about this document. Basics ¶ These are the basic features to get you started with Pointr Cloud. The current version of Pointr Cloud may be seen on the left menu bar after logging in. Login ¶ In order to use the available features of Pointr Cloud, go to the web address that is provided. This address will be of the form xxx.pointr.cloud or xxx.pointrlabs.comwhere you should replacexxxwith your unique domain name. Note that in special cases, your Pointr Cloud endpoint will differ, but you should already know this - if you’re unsure, get in touch Enter your login details into the form, and click login. For the login screen see the image below. The welcome email you receive when you first register will contain username information. If you forget this, you can always refer to the email. Image 1.1: The login screen. Request Access ¶ If you are not registered, or you have not received a welcome email, you may click on the “request access” link which is located below the “Log in” button shown in Image 1.2. Image 1.2: Login details. Clicking the request access button will trigger an email to your administrator. 1.1.2 Can’t remember your password? If you are given account details but cannot remember your password, you may click on the “password” link shown in Image 1.2, to request a new password. If a password request is attempted with an email address that is not a registered user, no action will be taken for security reasons. In case of too many attempts as a non- registered user, you will not be allowed access from the same device for a limited time. 1.2 Venue Selection You can select the venue that you wish to work on from the drop-down menu on the left menu bar, next to your company logo (See Image 1.3). Image 1.3: Venues. If a venue or a store does not show in the dropdown menu, this might be because: You might not have the privileges to see all the venues of your company. The venue has not been added on to the system. In order to be able to see a venue on the drop-down menu, contact support. Analyse These are the tools that enable you to analyse the data collected from users. 2.1 Analytics These charts show data gathered from wifi - i.e. POP devices. For charts that show analytics gathered from bluetooth data - i.e from beacons - see SDK Analytics screen. Image 2.4: Analytics charts. On this screen you have the option to visualise the data according to Various venues, Various user segments, Daily or hourly. Also on the upper right corner of the charts, you have the option to export the charts as .xls or .pdf files. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. If there are multiples venues on the Pointr Cloud to which you have access, you will also see these in tabs above each chart. You can select these tabs to view the charts for each venue. Note that the charts on this module are customisable. Please contact support to discuss if you wish to customise the analytics charts. 2.2 Zone Analytics This chart allows you to visualise the zone-wise data. To be able to see the analytics on this module, it is necessary to define “Zone” or “Customer Zone” as a POI at Map Designer. Image 2.5: Zone Analytics screen. You can select a start and end date that you wish to visualise the data for. You can see the date and time selection boxes on top of the screen on Image 2.5. Next to the date selection boxes you can choose either Footfall to view the number of users or Dwell Time to view the time spent. Underneath the date selection (or next to it - depending on your screen resolution), you will see a dropdown menu to select “count” or “percentage”. Here, you can also choose to visualise the data according to count at each zone or the percentage of the count compared to the rest of the same level. Permanent Tooltip is for keeping the numerical data on top of the map permanently. When you are ready, press the “Run” button to see the data appearing on the map. You can refer to the legend on the bottom-right corner of the map for colour-coding. If you have not selected Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. permanent tooltip, you can alternatively see the values by clicking on each zone as well. 2.3 Customer Flow This tool allows you to visualise the customer flow (or flux) data using colour-coded arrowheads. To be able to see the analytics on this module, it is necessary to define “Zone” or “Customer Zone” as a POI at Map Designer. It shows the count or percentage of users passing from one neighbouring zone to the other along with the direction of passage. Image 2.6: Customer Flow chart. The options on this screen are the following. You can select the date-time interval on the top of the screen. (See Image 2.6) You can choose to see a count of customers or percentage compared to the whole of the level on the dropdown menu next to date selection. When you are ready, you can press “Start” button to see the data on the map. You can refer to the legend on the bottom-right corner of the map for colour-coding. You can also hover on the arrowheads to see the numerical values for the transition between the two zones. 2.4 SDK Analytics In this section you can see an analysis of the data collected from SDK (software development kit) Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. by using four different graphs. You can view the graphs week by week, by choosing the week from the dropdown menu on each graph. These graphs are explained below. Number of Sessions shows the total number of sessions made using SDK in the chosen time period. For example one user uses SDK three times and another uses it four times. The total number of sessions of these two users is seven. Number of Calculated Paths shows the number times SDK users made a search and used the calculated path. Number of Searches shows the total number of searches done in the chosen time period including the paths not taken. Number of Unique Users shows the number of users excluding the revisits. For example, one user uses SDK three times and another uses it four times. The number of unique users is two here. Note that if a user uses the SDK and deletes the app, then they download it and use it again, they will show as another unique user as they are given a new ID every time they download the app. 2.5 Heatmap This feature enables the cloud users to produce heatmaps using the data acquired from visitors. You can manage which information the map will show by using the dropdown options underlined in blue in Image 2.7. Here you can also specify the date and time interval. Image 2.7: Heatmap data. The options you can choose in order of appearance in Image 2.7 is as follows. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. Floor selection: Select which floor information you want to see. You may also choose to see all the floors next to each other by selecting “All floors”. Type of data: You may either viewdwell timeorvisitor count. When you choose dwell time, the colours will represent the time spent in one region from red (the most) to green (the least). If you choose visitor count, then the colours will show, most number of visits (red) to least number of visits (green). Source: This option, by default, has value “All”. Here you can choose the source that the data comes from. This can be SDK, bluetooth, wi-fi, bluetooth and wifi, asset wi-fi, asset bluetooth, all of them, unknown, and error. The data is acquired from POP devices instead of beacons if the source is not SDK. Error shows data identified as error. And unknown shows data that could not be identified. Date: Here you can choose the date and time interval that you wish to see the data in. Basic/Advanced: When this button shows “Advanced”, you are on the advanced screen where you choose a start and end date for the data. If the button shows “Basic”, the time interval is one day by default and you do not need to set a start date. Note that this button is planned for deprecation. 2.6 Zone Heatmap In this module you can view heatmaps of the customer zones that you added on Map Designer as a POI layer, at least 24 hours before using this analytics tool. You can view the zone heatmaps in 24-hour intervals. Image 2.8: Zone heatmap screen. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. Select beginning and end date and time. The interval has to be a maximum of 24 hours. Select either Footfall to view the number of users or Dwell Time to view the time spent. Select “Permanent Tooltip” in order to view the count and percentage in a speech box on the map. When you click “Run”, you will see colour-coded map like that in Image 2.8. 2.7 Tracking Tracking allows for demonstration of active users’ locations as pin points. From the dropdown Image 2.9: Tracking screen. menus above the map, you can choose the following options. Floor Selection: Select which floor you want to see the data from. Source Selection: Select the source. The options are SDK, bluetooth, wi-fi, bluetooth and wi-fi, asset wi-fi, asset bluetooth, all, unknown, or error. Time Interval: Select the time interval you wish to see the data for, between now and a past time. This could be in minutes, hours, days, weeks, or months. 2.8 Simulation Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. Simulation feature allows you to animate the tracking data collected from the visitors. Note that this is not a simulation of predicted future data, rather this is an animation of the already collected data. You can choose the data you want to simulate from the menu bar above the map. The Image 2.10: Simulation screen. options, in order of appearance, are the following: User selection: You may either simulate data from one anonymous user, or you may select the “All Users” option to view all the users. Source selection: It is also possible to select the source that the data was taken by. This can be SDK, bluetooth, wi-fi, bluetooth and wi-fi, asset wi-fi, asset bluetooth, all, unknown, or error. Time interval: You may choose the time interval you wish to simulate. This function cannot show a duration of time of more than 6 hours. If you choose a duration more than six hours, you will get an error message saying “Please select a time interval shorter than 6 hours”. Show Trace: If this option is selected, the simulation will show all the routes that the users took. If unselected, the simulation will only show the starting and ending points. Colorized: If selected, the simulation will show each user with a different colour. If unse- lected, all users will be shown with a single colour. Speed: In this dropdown menu, the speed of the simulation may be selected. The options are 5x, 1x, 2x, 10x, 20x, 50x, fastest. For example 5x means the simulation will be 5 times faster than real time. The fastest option shows the simulation as fast as it can be. After customising your simulation using these buttons, press the play button to run the simulation. You will see a screen showing “Calculating”. Then the simulation will play if there data exists Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. between the time interval you chose. If there are not any data collected, then you will see the error message “No data found”. Image 2.11: Simulation demo. Each user’s activity can be identified by different colours. Manage These are the tools that allow you to manage the maps. 3.1 Map The map tool allows you to upload maps and make changes to existing maps. You can add maps by clicking on the “Add New Map Level” button on the top of the page. This will show you the screen in Image 3.12. Image 3.12: Add new map level. On this screen there are multiple things that you can do: Add a title. This is the title that the users will see on their devices. Specify the level. This has to be the actual floor level of the map. Add an optional description. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. Upload the map with the added information by using the “Done” button. You can make changes to and delete the existing maps by using the little button on the top right corner of the map. Image 3.13: Editting the map. The changes you can make include changing the description and name of the level, although floor level cannot be changed once created. This function allows you to upload two types of maps, namely “Main Map” and “Internal Map”. Main Map: Uploading a main map is essential. This is what the visitors will see on their devices. Internal Map: Uploading an internal map is optional. This is for internal use only. It will not be visible to visitors. The purpose of an additional internal map could be to upload maps that contain important/more detailed information for the Pointr Cloud users that may not be relevant to visitors. If no Internal Map is uploaded, only the Main Map will show. To make all the additions and the changes available to the users, it is essential to publish them by using the “Publish” button above the map(s). This button will appear faded as in Image 3.13 if no changes are made. 3.2 Map Designer This tool allows you to add and manage points of interest (POI), building information, and/or paths Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. on the maps. For a demonstration, you can watch the map designer demonstration video at this link: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0Bx_sE0zxh1AZUl9ESF9lY25sOTA/view?usp=sharing Choose the level you want to work with. Choose either one of Path Layer or POI Layer. Click on the box on the left of the items to see them on the map. If you see an eye symbol in the box, it means that these items are visible on the map. Remove the eye symbol from the items that you do not wish to view. 3.2.1 Adding path layer Click on Path Layer and make sure that it is highlighted red. Move the cursor on the map. You will see a cross where the cursor is. Click on the map with the cross where you wish the add the beginning node of the path. Then move the cursor to where you want to add the second node. This time you will see a dashed line extending from the first point to where the cursor is. If you click somewhere, this will mark the second node, and you will see a continuous line between two nodes. You can add as many nodes as you wish. In order to complete the path, either close the path by turning back to the beginning point, or click on the last node one more time. After doing so, you will not see a dashed line coming out of the last node any more until you start a new path. Image 3.14: Adding Path Layer. On the created path, you will see the nodes (in orange), a number in a red square in the middle of the continuous line, and if you zoom in, two arrows. (See Image 3.14.) The nodes are there to mark the start and end points of a straight path. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. The number in the red square defines the “speed” of this path. This number can be chosen between 1 and 9. This is to give the users an idea about which path is the fastest to reach their destination. In order to change the speed, right-click on the red box and simply change the number you see by typing. (See Image 3.15) If you right-click on the end node of the path, you will see a bin symbol. You can delete the path by clicking on the bin symbol. You may drag the node to change its location. To branch from an existing node, left-click and continue making the path. Editing the path: Right-click on the speed, in order to see the edit options. These options, in order of appearance from left to right, are the following: (See Image 3.15) Arrows determine the direction of the path. Some paths maybe only one-way or both ways. By clicking on the arrows, you can change the direction of the path. Bin symbol is to delete the path. The number defines the speed. The next symbol is a broken chain. By clicking on this symbol you can divide the path into two paths by adding a node in the middle. The next arrow has the same functionality as the first one. Image 3.15: Editting the path. Note that you will only see the arrows this large, if you zoom in. To save the path created, select the path by left-clicking on the number in the middle of the line and click “Save Current Level” button. For deleting, click on “Delete Selected Graph” button. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. Best Practices: for the way-finding to be able to find paths, the path layer needs to be continuous. If there are disconnected paths, it is very likely that the way-finding will not be able to find paths. the paths should not cross solid walls. bear in mind that the blue dot needs to have a line of sight to a path, otherwise way finding will show “could not find path” warning. Also note that after saving the path, click on the “Publish” button so that the result is published on the users’ screen. 3.2.2 Adding POI layer POI stands for P oint O f I nterest. Here you can add new POI Layers on your map and edit the existing ones. Image 3.16: POI Layer, drop-down menu options. POI Layer options: Analytics Zone/Event Zone: Mark the zones that the user segment analytics will be calcu- lated for in the Analytics screen. Customer Zone/Zone: Martk the zones to use in Zone Heatmap and Zone Analytics screen.When adding rectangles or polygons, note that the edges of neighbouring zones should overlap. Note that you will see analytics on the zone analytics module 24 hours after adding the zones here. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. External Trigger: Mark the zones for in-app notifications. The message to be triggered should be written in the “Description” box on the right side of the page. Facility: Mark the facilities inside the venue. Facilities are separate buildings inside one venue that are connected by a portal. IBeacon: Mark the iBeacons when Pointr beacons are not used. Pointr beacons are config- ured by Guru app and are added onto the map automatically as IBeacon. Interfacility Portal: Mark a vehicle or transportation that allows moving from one facility to another. (e.g. a train that connects terminals at airports) Lift: Mark the lifts. Note that all the levels that the lifts can go to should be stated. Master POP: Mark a POP device. POP devices should be added on the map as accurately as possible after configuring them. Service Lift: Mark lifts that are used only by the staff. Service Stairs: Mark stairs that are used only by the staff. Solid Walls: Mark the walls of the building. Also you can add solid walls where you do not wish the way finding to take the users through. Stairs: Mark the stairs. Note that for stairs there needs to be an upwards and a downwards stairs. Think of these as one-way road. Note that from each floor there should be a staircase going to one higher or one lower floor, also a staircase coming from one higher or one lower floor. The level that the stair can go up (or down) should be stated in the details. Thematic Area: Mark a zone that is subject to change (e.g. a Christmas stall.) Travelator: Mark a moving walkway. Trigger: Mark the zones where push notifications will be triggered. After marking the trigger zone, you can setup the details of this notification in the Notify User screen. How to add the POI Layer: Select the POI layer type from the drop-down menu. Read the guiding messages on the screen at every step. Click on the green plus symbol next to the drop-down menu. On the upper left side of the map, underneath the zoom option, select either one of the three shapes where they are available: rectangle, polygon, or pin. Note that for some POI layer types there are fewer shape options. (a) Rectangle: Make a rectangular shape. Click to start, let go to complete the shape. (b) Polygon: Free-drawing tool. You need to close the shape to complete. © Pin: Drop a pin mark. Click anywhere on the map to drop the pin. After completing the shape, enter the details on the right side of the map. For each POI option, you may be asked about different details. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3.1 Click either one of the Save, Delete, or Edit Shape buttons. Note that forLiftandStairsPOI types edit shape option will not appear. Publish the end result to the users by clicking on the Publish button on the upper left side of the screen. Notify User These are the tools that allow you to send messages to users and to manage the location and time settings for the notifications. 4.1 Composer Composer feature allows you to write messages and determine which users to send the mes- sage to as well as setting up the time and location for the messages if you want to trigger these messages. Image 4.17: Composer screen. In this screen you will see three boxes (See Image 4.17). At the left-most box, you can specify your audience if you are collecting data which specify such circumstances. In the middle box (See Image 4.17), you can create a “Whitelist” and/or a “Blacklist”. In whitelist you may add people whom you especially want to send the message to who may not be a part of Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3.1 specifications selected in the first box. In the black list, you can prevent people from getting the message. The users will appear with their long user ID numbers. In the third box (See Image 4.17), you write the message, and choose the time and conditions of the delivery of this message. Writing the message: You can choose to send either a regular message or a survey. You can type your message in the related box and/or share a link in the URL box. In the survey case, this link may be the link of a surveying website. Timing: You also have the option to time this message. You can either choose to send it immediately by ticking “Now”. Or you can select a later time by choosing “Later” if you do not wish to send immediately. Alternatively you can choose to trigger the message according to users’ locations or visit counts. In case you choose to trigger the message, a new box will open in order to determine the criteria for the triggering (See Image 4.18). Image 4.18: Trigger criteria. You can set-up the following parameters as triggering criteria. Date Range: Schedule the message to start and end on certain dates and times. Repeat Count: How many times you wish to repeat sending the message. Event: Add a location from the dropdown menu. The message will be triggered upon enter- ing or exiting this location. Trigger locations can be setup in Map Designer under POI layers. Time interval input: Type the time interval for the second visit. Note that if you enter a value Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3.1 for this parameter, you will see that the “number of visits” parameter will be 2, since it has to be at least two visits for there to be an interval. Dwell time: The message will be triggered after the user spent this much time in the selected area. Number of visits: The number of times the user needs to visit the location before the message is triggered. After setting these parameters click the “Add” button. Here you can add more criteria for this trigger job by clicking “Add in-order criterion” button, or you can add another independent criterion by clicking “Add out-of-order criterion” button. (See Image 4.19). Then click “Save for sending” button which is located in the third box. Image 4.19: Add criterion option. This is called apush job. You can view all the push jobs by clicking on “Push Job” from the side-bar. You can also view a schedule for the push jobs by clicking on “Schedule view” from the side-bar. Settings 5.1 Configure POP Configuration: Settings for the POP devices for the selected venue. Global Configuration: Set-up SDK parameters that will be valid across all the venues. Configuration: SDK configurations for the selected venue. This configuration will be priori- tised against the global configuration if they are different. Image 5.20: Beacon status screen. Beacon Status: View the activity status of all the beacons at the selected venue. (See Image 5.20) Here, green tick means that the beacon has been connected recently, and a red cross means that the beacon has not been connected for some time. This is very likely to mean that no one approached that beacon if the last activity is a close date, so the signal has not been registered. It might also mean that the beacon ran out of battery or broken down for some other reason but note that beacon batteries do not run out very often. Last activity of the beacon can be viewed in the column on the left of the activity status. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3.1 POP Status: View the activity of the POP device. Similar to the beacon activity screen, green tick means that the POP device has been connected recently, and a red cross means that the POP device has not been connected for some time. Note that if the device shows red cross this might mean that no one approached the device recently. It might also mean that the device is broken down if the last activity shows a far date. Image 5.21: POP status screen. Facilities: Facilities are the locations that have a seperate map in a venue. This could be a different terminal of an airport, or a personnel only area for a shopping centre. In this configuration, you can view, add, and manage the facilities if you have the permissions. Here internal identifier is a number that is used to identify this facility by Pointr. External identifier is the number that your company uses to identify this facility. Users: View a list of current users who use Pointr Cloud and add new users if you have the permissions. Device Black List: Add users to the black list in order to exclude them from analytics. For example you can add your employees devices on this list to exclude these devices from marketing analytics. 5.2 Change Password You can change your password in this screen. Your password should fit the criteria that is stated as red coloured next to the form. Type your old password in the first box and type your new password in the next two boxes. New password and Confirm new password must match. (See Image 5.22) Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3.1 Image 5.22: Change password screen. 5.3 Logout Pointr Cloud does not log you out automatically. It is recommended to save all the changes and to log out if you are leaving the computer for a long time, or if you are using a shared computer. Frequently Asked Questions 1. I did not get an email when I used the “Can’t remember password” option. What should I do? This could be because either one of these causes: You might be at an incorrect domain address. Your email might not be registered. Contact your admin to resolve this issue. Why can I not see a venue that I want to work on? If you cannot see a venue in the dropdown menu, this might be because your account has not been given access to it. Contact your admin to request access to the venue. I cannot see any data points on the graphs? - Make sure that you selected the correct time interval where some data should have been collected. - Make sure that the store is selected. - Check if the beacons or POP devices are working from Settings and Configurations. Heatmap/Simulation show visitor data on the map where they cannot go (e.g staff only areas, walls.) Make sure that the beacon or POP device coordinates are set up correctly on map designer if this is applicable. I added a map and saved it but it is not visible to app users. Make sure to publish the map after saving. Users can only see the map if it is published after saving. I want to add a POI layer type that is not one of the options. What can I do? Make sure that the POI type you wish to add cannot be added as one of the options in the drop- down list. Contact your admin. I select POI layer and click the green plus sign, nothing happens. What should I do? You should select one of the POI type options that is below “POI layer” in the dropdown menu. “POI layer” itself is not a POI layer type. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3.1 8. I want to add a path layer but the little plus sign does not appear. How do I add the path layer? Make sure that the Path Layer is selected and highlighted in red on the right menu. I cannot see path/POI layer that I added previously. - MAke sure that there is an eye symbol in the box left of path/POI layer option on the right menu. If there is not, click inside the box. Eye symbol means that the items are visible. - If the eye symbol is there and you still cannot see what you added previously, this means that you must have exited the page before saving and publishing. Make sure to click Save to save your progress and click Publish to make it available to the users. I cannot see the shape options whilst adding a POI layer. Zoom out and/or scroll up. The shape options appear on the upper left corner of the map. This is a offline tool, your data stays locally and is not send to any server! Feedback & Bug Reports
docs.title: Quickstart - Pointr Cloud

docs.text: Here you can find information about logging in, data analytics functions, map management, notification management, and settings and configurations, and other useful information. Disclaimer All maps and data shown in this document are for demonstration purposes only and not based on factual data. The images shown may differ in the document and on your screen depending on the user permissions and updates in Pointr Cloud. Email support in order to give feedback about this document.
docs.title: Get Started With Pointr Cloud

docs.text: These are the basic features to get you started with Pointr Cloud. The current version of Pointr Cloud may be seen on the left menu bar after logging in.
docs.title: Basics

docs.text: In order to use the available features of Pointr Cloud, go to the web address that is provided. This address will be of the form xxx.pointr.cloud or xxx.pointrlabs.comwhere you should replacexxxwith your unique domain name. Note that in special cases, your Pointr Cloud endpoint will differ, but you should already know this - if you’re unsure, get in touch Enter your login details into the form, and click login. For the login screen see the image below. The welcome email you receive when you first register will contain username information. If you forget this, you can always refer to the email. Image 1.1: The login screen.
docs.title: Login

docs.text: If you are not registered, or you have not received a welcome email, you may click on the “request access” link which is located below the “Log in” button shown in Image 1.2. Image 1.2: Login details. Clicking the request access button will trigger an email to your administrator. 1.1.2 Can’t remember your password? If you are given account details but cannot remember your password, you may click on the “password” link shown in Image 1.2, to request a new password. If a password request is attempted with an email address that is not a registered user, no action will be taken for security reasons. In case of too many attempts as a non- registered user, you will not be allowed access from the same device for a limited time. 1.2 Venue Selection You can select the venue that you wish to work on from the drop-down menu on the left menu bar, next to your company logo (See Image 1.3). Image 1.3: Venues. If a venue or a store does not show in the dropdown menu, this might be because: You might not have the privileges to see all the venues of your company. The venue has not been added on to the system. In order to be able to see a venue on the drop-down menu, contact support. Analyse These are the tools that enable you to analyse the data collected from users. 2.1 Analytics These charts show data gathered from wifi - i.e. POP devices. For charts that show analytics gathered from bluetooth data - i.e from beacons - see SDK Analytics screen. Image 2.4: Analytics charts. On this screen you have the option to visualise the data according to Various venues, Various user segments, Daily or hourly. Also on the upper right corner of the charts, you have the option to export the charts as .xls or .pdf files. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. If there are multiples venues on the Pointr Cloud to which you have access, you will also see these in tabs above each chart. You can select these tabs to view the charts for each venue. Note that the charts on this module are customisable. Please contact support to discuss if you wish to customise the analytics charts. 2.2 Zone Analytics This chart allows you to visualise the zone-wise data. To be able to see the analytics on this module, it is necessary to define “Zone” or “Customer Zone” as a POI at Map Designer. Image 2.5: Zone Analytics screen. You can select a start and end date that you wish to visualise the data for. You can see the date and time selection boxes on top of the screen on Image 2.5. Next to the date selection boxes you can choose either Footfall to view the number of users or Dwell Time to view the time spent. Underneath the date selection (or next to it - depending on your screen resolution), you will see a dropdown menu to select “count” or “percentage”. Here, you can also choose to visualise the data according to count at each zone or the percentage of the count compared to the rest of the same level. Permanent Tooltip is for keeping the numerical data on top of the map permanently. When you are ready, press the “Run” button to see the data appearing on the map. You can refer to the legend on the bottom-right corner of the map for colour-coding. If you have not selected Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. permanent tooltip, you can alternatively see the values by clicking on each zone as well. 2.3 Customer Flow This tool allows you to visualise the customer flow (or flux) data using colour-coded arrowheads. To be able to see the analytics on this module, it is necessary to define “Zone” or “Customer Zone” as a POI at Map Designer. It shows the count or percentage of users passing from one neighbouring zone to the other along with the direction of passage. Image 2.6: Customer Flow chart. The options on this screen are the following. You can select the date-time interval on the top of the screen. (See Image 2.6) You can choose to see a count of customers or percentage compared to the whole of the level on the dropdown menu next to date selection. When you are ready, you can press “Start” button to see the data on the map. You can refer to the legend on the bottom-right corner of the map for colour-coding. You can also hover on the arrowheads to see the numerical values for the transition between the two zones. 2.4 SDK Analytics In this section you can see an analysis of the data collected from SDK (software development kit) Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. by using four different graphs. You can view the graphs week by week, by choosing the week from the dropdown menu on each graph. These graphs are explained below. Number of Sessions shows the total number of sessions made using SDK in the chosen time period. For example one user uses SDK three times and another uses it four times. The total number of sessions of these two users is seven. Number of Calculated Paths shows the number times SDK users made a search and used the calculated path. Number of Searches shows the total number of searches done in the chosen time period including the paths not taken. Number of Unique Users shows the number of users excluding the revisits. For example, one user uses SDK three times and another uses it four times. The number of unique users is two here. Note that if a user uses the SDK and deletes the app, then they download it and use it again, they will show as another unique user as they are given a new ID every time they download the app. 2.5 Heatmap This feature enables the cloud users to produce heatmaps using the data acquired from visitors. You can manage which information the map will show by using the dropdown options underlined in blue in Image 2.7. Here you can also specify the date and time interval. Image 2.7: Heatmap data. The options you can choose in order of appearance in Image 2.7 is as follows. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. Floor selection: Select which floor information you want to see. You may also choose to see all the floors next to each other by selecting “All floors”. Type of data: You may either viewdwell timeorvisitor count. When you choose dwell time, the colours will represent the time spent in one region from red (the most) to green (the least). If you choose visitor count, then the colours will show, most number of visits (red) to least number of visits (green). Source: This option, by default, has value “All”. Here you can choose the source that the data comes from. This can be SDK, bluetooth, wi-fi, bluetooth and wifi, asset wi-fi, asset bluetooth, all of them, unknown, and error. The data is acquired from POP devices instead of beacons if the source is not SDK. Error shows data identified as error. And unknown shows data that could not be identified. Date: Here you can choose the date and time interval that you wish to see the data in. Basic/Advanced: When this button shows “Advanced”, you are on the advanced screen where you choose a start and end date for the data. If the button shows “Basic”, the time interval is one day by default and you do not need to set a start date. Note that this button is planned for deprecation. 2.6 Zone Heatmap In this module you can view heatmaps of the customer zones that you added on Map Designer as a POI layer, at least 24 hours before using this analytics tool. You can view the zone heatmaps in 24-hour intervals. Image 2.8: Zone heatmap screen. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. Select beginning and end date and time. The interval has to be a maximum of 24 hours. Select either Footfall to view the number of users or Dwell Time to view the time spent. Select “Permanent Tooltip” in order to view the count and percentage in a speech box on the map. When you click “Run”, you will see colour-coded map like that in Image 2.8. 2.7 Tracking Tracking allows for demonstration of active users’ locations as pin points. From the dropdown Image 2.9: Tracking screen. menus above the map, you can choose the following options. Floor Selection: Select which floor you want to see the data from. Source Selection: Select the source. The options are SDK, bluetooth, wi-fi, bluetooth and wi-fi, asset wi-fi, asset bluetooth, all, unknown, or error. Time Interval: Select the time interval you wish to see the data for, between now and a past time. This could be in minutes, hours, days, weeks, or months. 2.8 Simulation Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. Simulation feature allows you to animate the tracking data collected from the visitors. Note that this is not a simulation of predicted future data, rather this is an animation of the already collected data. You can choose the data you want to simulate from the menu bar above the map. The Image 2.10: Simulation screen. options, in order of appearance, are the following: User selection: You may either simulate data from one anonymous user, or you may select the “All Users” option to view all the users. Source selection: It is also possible to select the source that the data was taken by. This can be SDK, bluetooth, wi-fi, bluetooth and wi-fi, asset wi-fi, asset bluetooth, all, unknown, or error. Time interval: You may choose the time interval you wish to simulate. This function cannot show a duration of time of more than 6 hours. If you choose a duration more than six hours, you will get an error message saying “Please select a time interval shorter than 6 hours”. Show Trace: If this option is selected, the simulation will show all the routes that the users took. If unselected, the simulation will only show the starting and ending points. Colorized: If selected, the simulation will show each user with a different colour. If unse- lected, all users will be shown with a single colour. Speed: In this dropdown menu, the speed of the simulation may be selected. The options are 5x, 1x, 2x, 10x, 20x, 50x, fastest. For example 5x means the simulation will be 5 times faster than real time. The fastest option shows the simulation as fast as it can be. After customising your simulation using these buttons, press the play button to run the simulation. You will see a screen showing “Calculating”. Then the simulation will play if there data exists Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. between the time interval you chose. If there are not any data collected, then you will see the error message “No data found”. Image 2.11: Simulation demo. Each user’s activity can be identified by different colours. Manage These are the tools that allow you to manage the maps. 3.1 Map The map tool allows you to upload maps and make changes to existing maps. You can add maps by clicking on the “Add New Map Level” button on the top of the page. This will show you the screen in Image 3.12. Image 3.12: Add new map level. On this screen there are multiple things that you can do: Add a title. This is the title that the users will see on their devices. Specify the level. This has to be the actual floor level of the map. Add an optional description. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. Upload the map with the added information by using the “Done” button. You can make changes to and delete the existing maps by using the little button on the top right corner of the map. Image 3.13: Editting the map. The changes you can make include changing the description and name of the level, although floor level cannot be changed once created. This function allows you to upload two types of maps, namely “Main Map” and “Internal Map”. Main Map: Uploading a main map is essential. This is what the visitors will see on their devices. Internal Map: Uploading an internal map is optional. This is for internal use only. It will not be visible to visitors. The purpose of an additional internal map could be to upload maps that contain important/more detailed information for the Pointr Cloud users that may not be relevant to visitors. If no Internal Map is uploaded, only the Main Map will show. To make all the additions and the changes available to the users, it is essential to publish them by using the “Publish” button above the map(s). This button will appear faded as in Image 3.13 if no changes are made. 3.2 Map Designer This tool allows you to add and manage points of interest (POI), building information, and/or paths Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. on the maps. For a demonstration, you can watch the map designer demonstration video at this link: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0Bx_sE0zxh1AZUl9ESF9lY25sOTA/view?usp=sharing Choose the level you want to work with. Choose either one of Path Layer or POI Layer. Click on the box on the left of the items to see them on the map. If you see an eye symbol in the box, it means that these items are visible on the map. Remove the eye symbol from the items that you do not wish to view. 3.2.1 Adding path layer Click on Path Layer and make sure that it is highlighted red. Move the cursor on the map. You will see a cross where the cursor is. Click on the map with the cross where you wish the add the beginning node of the path. Then move the cursor to where you want to add the second node. This time you will see a dashed line extending from the first point to where the cursor is. If you click somewhere, this will mark the second node, and you will see a continuous line between two nodes. You can add as many nodes as you wish. In order to complete the path, either close the path by turning back to the beginning point, or click on the last node one more time. After doing so, you will not see a dashed line coming out of the last node any more until you start a new path. Image 3.14: Adding Path Layer. On the created path, you will see the nodes (in orange), a number in a red square in the middle of the continuous line, and if you zoom in, two arrows. (See Image 3.14.) The nodes are there to mark the start and end points of a straight path. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. The number in the red square defines the “speed” of this path. This number can be chosen between 1 and 9. This is to give the users an idea about which path is the fastest to reach their destination. In order to change the speed, right-click on the red box and simply change the number you see by typing. (See Image 3.15) If you right-click on the end node of the path, you will see a bin symbol. You can delete the path by clicking on the bin symbol. You may drag the node to change its location. To branch from an existing node, left-click and continue making the path. Editing the path: Right-click on the speed, in order to see the edit options. These options, in order of appearance from left to right, are the following: (See Image 3.15) Arrows determine the direction of the path. Some paths maybe only one-way or both ways. By clicking on the arrows, you can change the direction of the path. Bin symbol is to delete the path. The number defines the speed. The next symbol is a broken chain. By clicking on this symbol you can divide the path into two paths by adding a node in the middle. The next arrow has the same functionality as the first one. Image 3.15: Editting the path. Note that you will only see the arrows this large, if you zoom in. To save the path created, select the path by left-clicking on the number in the middle of the line and click “Save Current Level” button. For deleting, click on “Delete Selected Graph” button. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. Best Practices: for the way-finding to be able to find paths, the path layer needs to be continuous. If there are disconnected paths, it is very likely that the way-finding will not be able to find paths. the paths should not cross solid walls. bear in mind that the blue dot needs to have a line of sight to a path, otherwise way finding will show “could not find path” warning. Also note that after saving the path, click on the “Publish” button so that the result is published on the users’ screen. 3.2.2 Adding POI layer POI stands for P oint O f I nterest. Here you can add new POI Layers on your map and edit the existing ones. Image 3.16: POI Layer, drop-down menu options. POI Layer options: Analytics Zone/Event Zone: Mark the zones that the user segment analytics will be calcu- lated for in the Analytics screen. Customer Zone/Zone: Martk the zones to use in Zone Heatmap and Zone Analytics screen.When adding rectangles or polygons, note that the edges of neighbouring zones should overlap. Note that you will see analytics on the zone analytics module 24 hours after adding the zones here. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3. External Trigger: Mark the zones for in-app notifications. The message to be triggered should be written in the “Description” box on the right side of the page. Facility: Mark the facilities inside the venue. Facilities are separate buildings inside one venue that are connected by a portal. IBeacon: Mark the iBeacons when Pointr beacons are not used. Pointr beacons are config- ured by Guru app and are added onto the map automatically as IBeacon. Interfacility Portal: Mark a vehicle or transportation that allows moving from one facility to another. (e.g. a train that connects terminals at airports) Lift: Mark the lifts. Note that all the levels that the lifts can go to should be stated. Master POP: Mark a POP device. POP devices should be added on the map as accurately as possible after configuring them. Service Lift: Mark lifts that are used only by the staff. Service Stairs: Mark stairs that are used only by the staff. Solid Walls: Mark the walls of the building. Also you can add solid walls where you do not wish the way finding to take the users through. Stairs: Mark the stairs. Note that for stairs there needs to be an upwards and a downwards stairs. Think of these as one-way road. Note that from each floor there should be a staircase going to one higher or one lower floor, also a staircase coming from one higher or one lower floor. The level that the stair can go up (or down) should be stated in the details. Thematic Area: Mark a zone that is subject to change (e.g. a Christmas stall.) Travelator: Mark a moving walkway. Trigger: Mark the zones where push notifications will be triggered. After marking the trigger zone, you can setup the details of this notification in the Notify User screen. How to add the POI Layer: Select the POI layer type from the drop-down menu. Read the guiding messages on the screen at every step. Click on the green plus symbol next to the drop-down menu. On the upper left side of the map, underneath the zoom option, select either one of the three shapes where they are available: rectangle, polygon, or pin. Note that for some POI layer types there are fewer shape options. (a) Rectangle: Make a rectangular shape. Click to start, let go to complete the shape. (b) Polygon: Free-drawing tool. You need to close the shape to complete. © Pin: Drop a pin mark. Click anywhere on the map to drop the pin. After completing the shape, enter the details on the right side of the map. For each POI option, you may be asked about different details. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3.1 Click either one of the Save, Delete, or Edit Shape buttons. Note that forLiftandStairsPOI types edit shape option will not appear. Publish the end result to the users by clicking on the Publish button on the upper left side of the screen. Notify User These are the tools that allow you to send messages to users and to manage the location and time settings for the notifications. 4.1 Composer Composer feature allows you to write messages and determine which users to send the mes- sage to as well as setting up the time and location for the messages if you want to trigger these messages. Image 4.17: Composer screen. In this screen you will see three boxes (See Image 4.17). At the left-most box, you can specify your audience if you are collecting data which specify such circumstances. In the middle box (See Image 4.17), you can create a “Whitelist” and/or a “Blacklist”. In whitelist you may add people whom you especially want to send the message to who may not be a part of Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3.1 specifications selected in the first box. In the black list, you can prevent people from getting the message. The users will appear with their long user ID numbers. In the third box (See Image 4.17), you write the message, and choose the time and conditions of the delivery of this message. Writing the message: You can choose to send either a regular message or a survey. You can type your message in the related box and/or share a link in the URL box. In the survey case, this link may be the link of a surveying website. Timing: You also have the option to time this message. You can either choose to send it immediately by ticking “Now”. Or you can select a later time by choosing “Later” if you do not wish to send immediately. Alternatively you can choose to trigger the message according to users’ locations or visit counts. In case you choose to trigger the message, a new box will open in order to determine the criteria for the triggering (See Image 4.18). Image 4.18: Trigger criteria. You can set-up the following parameters as triggering criteria. Date Range: Schedule the message to start and end on certain dates and times. Repeat Count: How many times you wish to repeat sending the message. Event: Add a location from the dropdown menu. The message will be triggered upon enter- ing or exiting this location. Trigger locations can be setup in Map Designer under POI layers. Time interval input: Type the time interval for the second visit. Note that if you enter a value Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3.1 for this parameter, you will see that the “number of visits” parameter will be 2, since it has to be at least two visits for there to be an interval. Dwell time: The message will be triggered after the user spent this much time in the selected area. Number of visits: The number of times the user needs to visit the location before the message is triggered. After setting these parameters click the “Add” button. Here you can add more criteria for this trigger job by clicking “Add in-order criterion” button, or you can add another independent criterion by clicking “Add out-of-order criterion” button. (See Image 4.19). Then click “Save for sending” button which is located in the third box. Image 4.19: Add criterion option. This is called apush job. You can view all the push jobs by clicking on “Push Job” from the side-bar. You can also view a schedule for the push jobs by clicking on “Schedule view” from the side-bar. Settings 5.1 Configure POP Configuration: Settings for the POP devices for the selected venue. Global Configuration: Set-up SDK parameters that will be valid across all the venues. Configuration: SDK configurations for the selected venue. This configuration will be priori- tised against the global configuration if they are different. Image 5.20: Beacon status screen. Beacon Status: View the activity status of all the beacons at the selected venue. (See Image 5.20) Here, green tick means that the beacon has been connected recently, and a red cross means that the beacon has not been connected for some time. This is very likely to mean that no one approached that beacon if the last activity is a close date, so the signal has not been registered. It might also mean that the beacon ran out of battery or broken down for some other reason but note that beacon batteries do not run out very often. Last activity of the beacon can be viewed in the column on the left of the activity status. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3.1 POP Status: View the activity of the POP device. Similar to the beacon activity screen, green tick means that the POP device has been connected recently, and a red cross means that the POP device has not been connected for some time. Note that if the device shows red cross this might mean that no one approached the device recently. It might also mean that the device is broken down if the last activity shows a far date. Image 5.21: POP status screen. Facilities: Facilities are the locations that have a seperate map in a venue. This could be a different terminal of an airport, or a personnel only area for a shopping centre. In this configuration, you can view, add, and manage the facilities if you have the permissions. Here internal identifier is a number that is used to identify this facility by Pointr. External identifier is the number that your company uses to identify this facility. Users: View a list of current users who use Pointr Cloud and add new users if you have the permissions. Device Black List: Add users to the black list in order to exclude them from analytics. For example you can add your employees devices on this list to exclude these devices from marketing analytics. 5.2 Change Password You can change your password in this screen. Your password should fit the criteria that is stated as red coloured next to the form. Type your old password in the first box and type your new password in the next two boxes. New password and Confirm new password must match. (See Image 5.22) Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3.1 Image 5.22: Change password screen. 5.3 Logout Pointr Cloud does not log you out automatically. It is recommended to save all the changes and to log out if you are leaving the computer for a long time, or if you are using a shared computer. Frequently Asked Questions 1. I did not get an email when I used the “Can’t remember password” option. What should I do? This could be because either one of these causes: You might be at an incorrect domain address. Your email might not be registered. Contact your admin to resolve this issue. Why can I not see a venue that I want to work on? If you cannot see a venue in the dropdown menu, this might be because your account has not been given access to it. Contact your admin to request access to the venue. I cannot see any data points on the graphs? - Make sure that you selected the correct time interval where some data should have been collected. - Make sure that the store is selected. - Check if the beacons or POP devices are working from Settings and Configurations. Heatmap/Simulation show visitor data on the map where they cannot go (e.g staff only areas, walls.) Make sure that the beacon or POP device coordinates are set up correctly on map designer if this is applicable. I added a map and saved it but it is not visible to app users. Make sure to publish the map after saving. Users can only see the map if it is published after saving. I want to add a POI layer type that is not one of the options. What can I do? Make sure that the POI type you wish to add cannot be added as one of the options in the drop- down list. Contact your admin. I select POI layer and click the green plus sign, nothing happens. What should I do? You should select one of the POI type options that is below “POI layer” in the dropdown menu. “POI layer” itself is not a POI layer type. Pointr Cloud Tutorial v3.1 8. I want to add a path layer but the little plus sign does not appear. How do I add the path layer? Make sure that the Path Layer is selected and highlighted in red on the right menu. I cannot see path/POI layer that I added previously. - MAke sure that there is an eye symbol in the box left of path/POI layer option on the right menu. If there is not, click inside the box. Eye symbol means that the items are visible. - If the eye symbol is there and you still cannot see what you added previously, this means that you must have exited the page before saving and publishing. Make sure to click Save to save your progress and click Publish to make it available to the users. I cannot see the shape options whilst adding a POI layer. Zoom out and/or scroll up. The shape options appear on the upper left corner of the map. This is a offline tool, your data stays locally and is not send to any server! Feedback & Bug Reports
docs.title: Request Access

docs.text: Pointr Cloud Authentication Guide ¶ Introduction Pointr Cloud is a web based content management system which has three main functions: Enables clients to manage their content such as maps, POIs, and venue configurations, Provides an API for Pointr SDK and third party softwares, Displays analytic dashboards such as Heatmap, Zone Analytics, and Position Simulation. Pointr Cloud Authentication Pointr Cloud is SSL enabled and establishes a secure connection with the client. Authentication to Pointr Cloud can be achieved with three methods. Form Authentication ¶ Users can access Pointr Cloud through web browsers by using their username and passwords. After consecutive unsuccessful attempts, users either can be blocked by an IP address for an hour or are shown reCAPTCHA to avoid misuse. Azure Active Directory Authentication ¶ If Azure active directory authentication is enabled and settings are configured on Pointr Cloud, users can login to Pointr Cloud by clicking “Sign in via Azure” button after they are already logged in on their Azure account on browser. (2FA) Google Authentication can also be enabled per request. If enabled, users are asked for authentication token after they successfully entered their username and password. Token Authentication ¶ Pointr SDK and API clients use this authentication method. Each request should provide the following HTTP headers for authentication: DeviceIdentifer: Unique identifier of SDK client or API user, AuthenticationToken: User specific authentication token provided by Pointr Cloud. Unique Identifiers Pointr SDK creates a unique identifier for a device when first installed, and registers the device to Pointr Cloud to receive an authentication token. After registration process, Pointr SDK uses this device identifier and authentication token pair in each request to authenticate to Pointr Cloud. You can read more about these here . For API users, authentication tokens are created by Pointr Cloud team per request of the client.
docs.title: Authentication - Pointr Cloud

docs.text: Configuration Files ¶ For flexibility, Pointr Mobile SDK is configured by a set of rich configuration options. Most Pointr SDK Components are initialised by Configuration Values, and most features can be enabled or disabled, or altered, through the supplied Configuration Files. CoreConfiguration is the top level configuration file, it consists of a configuration option for each SDK Manager. These are named in the following convention: item description positionManagerConfiguration Provides positioning management interface and callbacks geofenceManagerConfiguration Object provides management and options for Geofencing etc… you can find out more here In addition, CoreConfiguration also contains configuration options for various other components of the SDK, for instance, consider the following: item description userInterfaceConfiguration For customising the UI properties present in the default Map Widget. Debug options are also available here. networkConfiguration Configuration for network requests to your Pointr Cloud instance etc… you can find out more here All configuration parameters can be edited via local configuration files (eg. BaseConfiguration.json or venue or facility specific configuration files) Please note the following… BaseConfiguration.json is only parsed upon first installation of the SDK. If you need to make any changes to this file, you need to uninstall the application containing the SDK and carry out a fresh install. For each Facility mapWidth , mapHeight , minLevel , maxLevel , facilityId and headingOffset must be provided (either via the Bundle file, or on Pointr Cloud ). Otherwise, the SDK will report an error.
docs.title: Configuration Files

docs.text: For flexibility, Pointr Mobile SDK is configured by a set of rich configuration options. Most Pointr SDK Components are initialised by Configuration Values, and most features can be enabled or disabled, or altered, through the supplied Configuration Files. CoreConfiguration is the top level configuration file, it consists of a configuration option for each SDK Manager. These are named in the following convention: item description positionManagerConfiguration Provides positioning management interface and callbacks geofenceManagerConfiguration Object provides management and options for Geofencing etc… you can find out more here In addition, CoreConfiguration also contains configuration options for various other components of the SDK, for instance, consider the following: item description userInterfaceConfiguration For customising the UI properties present in the default Map Widget. Debug options are also available here. networkConfiguration Configuration for network requests to your Pointr Cloud instance etc… you can find out more here All configuration parameters can be edited via local configuration files (eg. BaseConfiguration.json or venue or facility specific configuration files) Please note the following… BaseConfiguration.json is only parsed upon first installation of the SDK. If you need to make any changes to this file, you need to uninstall the application containing the SDK and carry out a fresh install. For each Facility mapWidth , mapHeight , minLevel , maxLevel , facilityId and headingOffset must be provided (either via the Bundle file, or on Pointr Cloud ). Otherwise, the SDK will report an error.

docs.text: Bluetooth Beacons ¶ Looking for POP? At Pointr we have developed our own state-of-the-art hardware solution, named POP® (Pointr of Presence) that powers our App-Free Analytics services. This provides data without using an Application, but is a difference kind of experience. You can read more about POPs here . We also make smart use of Bluetooth® Beacons, Pointr does not manufacture these, and we ensure to stay hardware-agnostic to be as flexible as possible. What are Beacons? ¶ A Beacon is a small device (approx 3cm x 5cm x 2cm) that constantly sends out radio signals, sometimes containing a small amount of data, that can be understood by nearby smartphones and tablets. They are very easy to install, typically have a long battery life (of ~3 years), and no cabling or any additional infrastructure is required. They come in many colours, shapes and sizes, and from many manufacturers, but at Pointr we are hardware agnostic, and can work with any Beacons you have, or recommend you some of our existing trusted suppliers. Different Beacons also suit different environments, and we can help advise the most suitable option for you. What are the “Signals” are sent by Beacons? ¶ The signal strength and time between each signal can be configured to give a desired coverage. Mobile apps can listen for the signals being broadcast and, when they hear a relevant signal, can trigger an action on your device. Beacons talk, the don’t listen Beacons only work in one direction (i.e. they can broadcast data, but they can not listen). For the majority of Beacons already out there, the data transmitted is hard coded and doesn’t change frequently (i.e. set it once when configuring the Beacon), and they rely on the listening device to do something intelligent with the data. Although this will likely change with the emergence of newer and higher level Bluetooth Low Energy technologies. How do they work? ¶ Beacons work using Bluetooth® Low Energy (also known as “BLE”) which is a version of the more common Bluetooth protocol, it is designed to use very little power, and send less data – typically 1-20% of standard Bluetooth power, and at 15-50% of the speed. They are often powered by batteries and as such the performance/battery life needs careful balancing to suit the application as the battery life can be anywhere from 1 month to 2-3 years (there are beacons using USB/mains power or solar panels so last much longer, and some beacons are coming out which are built into lights or light sockets). The beacons themselves are typically stuck to walls/ceilings or hidden in other objects since you can detect a beacon up to 70m away with no obstructions (depending on the power level). What is the effective range? ¶ Beacons can have up to 70m range with no obstructions, this can vary significantly, especially through walls and materials that are made with metal or brick (though thin/stud walls have a small impact on range). Info In addition to the potential range of Bluetooth Low Energy, most protocols also operate with three ranges of distance: far, near and immediate – and a device can do something different at each range: Far: this is designed so that your device can do something when you can just about hear a beacon (i.e. walking past a store) Near: this is designed so your device can do something once you are in the same room as a beacon (i.e. walking into a store) Immediate: this is designed so your device can do something once you are virtually touching a beacon (i.e. touching an advert or checkout in a shop) One key usage of Bluetooth Low Energy is to recognise how you move through these ranges and then offer experiences such as a welcome/goodbye message as you do some shopping, and even help you understand which parts of the shop you interacted with. It’s important to remember that this processing would have to be done by an Application running on a device, as a Beacon only transmits data, and cannot receive a signal from your device – this information could however be transmitted back to the Shop via a data/Wi-Fi connection. Are Beacons supported by iPhone / Android / Windows phones? ¶ Yes, all modern phones can support Bluetooth Low Energy but you have to turn on Bluetooth for anything to happen. On iOS 7 and above (iPhone 4s and above, iPad 3 rd /4 th Gen/Mini/Air, iPod Touch 5 th Gen and above), the phone can constantly scan for Bluetooth Low Energy devices and wake up relevant apps when they come within range of a relevant beacon (even if they are closed). On Android devices there is typically no dedicated operating-system management of Beacons, and often the apps must scan for Bluetooth Low Energy devices themselves. This means the apps must be running (can be in the background) all the time and hence use up more battery (not very much). On Windows Phone and Blackberry devices there are varying levels of compatibility, but most modern devices over the last few years support Bluetooth Low Energy in a similar way to Android (e.g. Windows phones require the Lumia Cyan update). Will it use up all my battery? ¶ No, unlike Active Bluetooth, receiving signals from Bluetooth Low Energy Beacons uses a lot less power than you might think. Leaving Bluetooth running on a device will typically use 1-3% of a total battery over the course of a full day – though if you are using standard (“Active”) Bluetooth at the same time (e.g. leaving Bluetooth headphones connected) then this can increase. Well, how is an iBeacon different to a regular Bluetooth Beacon? ¶ It’s not really, iBeacon is a protocol devised by Apple that aims to standardise the data broadcast by Bluetooth Beacons. In other words, iBeacon is an Apple flavour, running on top of core Bluetooth Low Energy technology and Beacons. Any Bluetooth Beacon can be configured as an iBeacon, as long as it transmits data according to Apple’s standards. Currently Apple doesn’t manufacture Beacon hardware, and expect Beacon vendors to adopt their iBeacon requirements. There is a chance that Apple may release their own iBeacon hardware, and at this point we may see a change. How much do Beacons cost? ¶ Due to their simple and lightweight nature, in large volumes Bluetooth Beacons can be incredibly inexpensive. You can pick one up for about £5-£25 depending on the features and battery life you want from it. What kind of data do Beacons send to devices? ¶ Contrary to common understanding, Beacons themselves transmit no meaningful data. Instead, they transmit short identifiers and it is an Application or other software that should make use of this information and do something useful. For Example… An Application can detect a seemingly-random number that was broadcast by a Beacon, then connect to internet to convert this number into a message, and then trigger a notifcation on the device. In short, beacons are dummy devices that advertise short identifiers, and it is the app that is responsible for doing something smart. But what does that mean really? ¶ Technically speaking, Beacons send a small stream of data containing a unique identifier and a small amount of customisable data. The identifier is what notifies an app to start listening and do something, while the data then gives some further information for processing. The identifier consists of three parts: a “UUID” which is typically the ID of the beacon vendor and a “Major” and “Minor” ID which are customisable and designed to signify different countries/regions/buildings/stores/rooms. The data is all transmitted unencrypted (by design) in a widely publicised format to ensure standardisation between manufacturers and platforms and as such can be spoofed. Apps need to understand this aspect of Bluetooth Beacon implementations to ensure that nothing sensitive is transmitted through Bluetooth Low Energy, and instead it should trigger a secure process. What interference do Beacons cause? ¶ Beacons do operate on the same frequency as some Wi-Fi signals (2.4GHz) and hence could cause interference, however they operate at lower power levels and transmit signals for very short periods of time – often for 1ms in a second (1000ms). As a result of this, even with many users simultaneously using Bluetooth, it is unlikely to have an effect on a Wi-Fi connection – there are loads of common household devices using this frequency band with much higher power levels and most of the time even they don’t have an effect. If the Wi-Fi connection is based on 5Ghz transmission then you will not get any interference at all.
docs.title: Bluetooth Beacons

docs.text: Integrate with Pointr Mobile SDK ¶ Welcome to Pointr Before you can begin you’ll need to have: A valid Pointr SDK API key A development environment for Android or iOS A supported device for testing What is Pointr SDK? ¶ Our SDK is a mobile software library, natively developed and actively supported for iOS and Android mobile platforms by Pointr. When integrated, it enables mobile applications to offer location based features such as blue dot positioning, wayfinding, location sharing and more. Pointr SDK uploads position data to Pointr Cloud , which can show real-time tracking or calculate analytics such as heatmaps. Who uses Pointr SDK? ¶ Pointr SDK is preferred by large venue owners or operators who want to offer location based services or marketing to their mobile application users whilst collecting location data about their users. Pointr’s primary markets are retail, airports (and travel hubs such as train stations) and industrial (such as factories and construction sites). How does Pointr SDK compare to other Indoor Location Libraries? Pointr are experts in indoor location and have been focusing on this field since it was started. Pointr SDK is the only SDK that provides: Very high accuracy (1 metre, patents pending) Multiplatform experience (both iOS and Android) Low battery use Highly scalable Highly customisable All using very low beacon density (approx. 1 beacon / 200 sqm) Where do I begin? ¶ Pointr SDK is shared privately with customers. On iOS, it is shared as a .framework ​ or ​ .embeddedframework file which can be drag & dropped into an iOS project. On Android, it is shared as a ​ .aar ​file through Pointr’s build server (using Artifactory). You will need to have a username and API key which needs to get included in the project Build.gradle file, along with the Pointr server URL as a Maven repository. Setup - Android ¶ You can find the Android guide here Setup - iOS ¶ You can find the iOS guide here Starting Pointr SDK ¶ To start successfully, Pointr SDK requires BaseConfiguration.json License key Pointr SDK cannot start without BaseConfiguration.json or license key. ¶ BaseConfiguration.json is a JSON file that includes required information such as baseUrl: Endpoint for Pointr Cloud (eg. ​ https://clientname.pointrlabs.com ​) uuidList: List of all UUID’s of beacons to detect beaconBrandName: Brand name of installed beacon hardware (eg. “kontakt” for Kontakt.io beacons, “gcell” for GCell beacons, “estimote” for Estimote beacons) License key: a long text key consisting of alphanumeric characters, separated by dashes. Eg. “AAAAAAAA-BBBB-CCCC-DDDD-EEEEEEEEEEEE” Steps: Include BaseConfiguration.json in the project Call Pointr.start method which requires a license key, among other parameters Observe Pointr.start callbacks for state changes (see Pointr States below) Pointr SDK Startup States ¶ Pointr SDK goes through several states during start up / stop, these are: State Description Off Pointr SDK is not started or it is stopped. Configuring Pointr SDK is starting and it is currently setting configuration. Validating Pointr SDK is starting and it is currently validating license key. Registering Pointr SDK is starting and it is currently registering device with Pointr Cloud . Running Pointr SDK is started successfully and it is currently running NOTE : this doesn’t necessarily mean you will get a bluedot as there are other configuration steps to follow That’s it! If everything worked correctly then you have now successfully integrated Pointr SDK. If you are having issues with something SDK-Related, please visit troubleshooting and faqs Don’t forget - if you can’t still find what you’re looking for and you need some help, you can always for get in touch
docs.title: Getting Started

docs.text: Configuration Files ¶ For flexibility, Pointr Mobile SDK is configured by a set of rich configuration options. Most Pointr SDK Components are initialised by Configuration Values, and most features can be enabled or disabled, or altered, through the supplied Configuration Files. CoreConfiguration is the top level configuration file, it consists of a configuration option for each SDK Manager. These are named in the following convention: item description positionManagerConfiguration Provides positioning management interface and callbacks geofenceManagerConfiguration Object provides management and options for Geofencing etc… you can find out more here In addition, CoreConfiguration also contains configuration options for various other components of the SDK, for instance, consider the following: item description userInterfaceConfiguration For customising the UI properties present in the default Map Widget. Debug options are also available here. networkConfiguration Configuration for network requests to your Pointr Cloud instance etc… you can find out more here All configuration parameters can be edited via local configuration files (eg. BaseConfiguration.json or venue or facility specific configuration files) Please note the following… BaseConfiguration.json is only parsed upon first installation of the SDK. If you need to make any changes to this file, you need to uninstall the application containing the SDK and carry out a fresh install. For each Facility mapWidth , mapHeight , minLevel , maxLevel , facilityId and headingOffset must be provided (either via the Bundle file, or on Pointr Cloud ). Otherwise, the SDK will report an error.
docs.title: Configuring Pointr Mobile SDK
