docs.text: DataManagement ¶ Overview ¶ When we refer to DataManagement , we are speaking about synchronisation of data from Pointr Cloud to a given Pointr SDK Instance If you want to know how your Pointr Cloud content is managed, you came to the right place… DataManagement includes synchronisation of data for the following types: Configuration Maps ( raster - see note below) Maps ( tiled - see note below) POIs Walls Graph We designed the SDK with a goal of causing as little disruption as possible, ensuring user always views up-to-date content, without using too much data bandwidth or power To achieve this we have taken the following steps: Offline/Online ¶ Pointr SDK supports both offline and online DataManagement Offline data management refers to using content files that are packaged with the project (eg. in the same bundle on iOS, in assets / resources folder on Android). Online data management refers to connecting to Pointr Cloud to pull latest published content and updating local device storage accordingly. Versioned Content Updates ¶ When Pointr SDK starts, it first checks for locally saved versions available to process (if offline) or download (if online). Pointr SDK only download a specific type of data (eg. POI’s) if it detects a newer version available (either in bundle or on server). Otherwise, it does not carry out update for that specific type of data. Raster and Tile Maps ¶ Maps are first downloaded as Raster Maps to display quickly, but they are replaced with Tiled Maps once these become available. Raster maps are noticibly lower quality, but doing this will ensure that your user can immediately start having a responsive map experience without blocking the UI thread, using lots of Mobile Data, or waiting for a long period Lazy Updates ¶ By default, Pointr SDK will only check for data updates while starting the SDK in the foreground Triggering Updates You can also trigger DataManagement updates by calling DataManager’s start functions, although we strongly recommend against doing this in the default case. Silent update mechanism ¶ Pointr is capable of updating silently. This is an optional feature and requires push notification capability to work. This all SDK instances to update their content as soon as new content is published to Pointr Cloud. Please note If you plan to make frequent data changes… … especially in local content files, uninstalling the application and then carry out a fresh install will ensure that all data is updated immediately. Otherwise, if you update local files and run the application again (without re-installing), Pointr SDK will note the versions of the content and assume that the device already has the latest content set, so an update will not occur. If you plan to switch between different Pointr Cloud environments… … then uninstall all application instances, and carry out a fresh install to ensure that all data changes are reflected. Otherwise, SDK will get confused between data file versions between DEV and QA. For example, if SDK has downloaded Poi content from DEV environment which had version 100, and then you switch to QA environment which as different Poi content but at version 50, it will not pull Poi content from QA since 100 is higher than 50.
docs.title: DataManagement

docs.text: Pointr Data Privacy Guide ¶ Overview ¶ Pointr Mobile SDK ¶ Pointr Mobile SDK is a native mobile library, available for iOS and Android (at the time of this writing), designed to enable many features such as indoor positioning, indoor navigation, point of interest search and more. It is typically embedded into client mobile applications for enabling these features (rather than being served standalone). Pointr Mobile SDK supports offline functionality for all essential parts, however, it will synchronise with Pointr Cloud as necessary to carry out activities such as: Downloading latest venue content (maps, points of interest, navigation information, etc.) Uploading user device position (both cached and real-time) Uploading user analytics Pointr POP Devices ¶ The Point of Presence (aka “ POP ”) consists of both WiFi and Bluetooth sensors. It captures any smart device (released in the last ~6 years and has WiFi enabled) that’s in proximity (within ~50 metres). Data gathered through this process includes: Approximate location of device and time An Anonymous Identifier for the device Whether this device has been within the venue before Approximate location history of the device within the venue Note All data captured is strictly anonymous and contains no item of user identifiable information. Based on data gathered by POP devices , Pointr Cloud provides analytical reports on visits, durations and dwell times, and more. Pointr Cloud ¶ Pointr Cloud is our Cloud-Hosted* web dashboard that includes our content management system (CMS), analytics, marketing and general configuration/maintenance dashboards. Pointr Cloud consists of several modules, some are required but some are optional. The main analytical modules include Heatmap, Tracking, Simulation, Customer Flow and Zone Analytics. These provide insight into how users move about the venue and utilise the space. On-premise deployment also available Device ID ¶ Pointr Mobile SDK and POP both aim to identify the user device. Identifier used by each are explained below: Pointr Mobile SDK (iOS) ¶ Pointr follows Apple’s official recommendation for identifying devices, utilising the device identifier method available in the default iOS SDK (since iOS 6). At the time of writing, it is UIDevice - identifierForVendor Method. Further documentation can be found here Pointr Mobile SDK (Android) ¶ On Android, Pointr Mobile SDK generates a globally unique identifier string when SDK instance is first installed, to be used as device identifier for this device. Pointr POP ¶ POP hardware detects devices by what they advertise in WiFi or BLE. For WiFi, devices advertise correct or false MAC identifier values of their networking equipment on board. For BLE, devices advertise a peripheral identifier. POP detects these values and submits them to Pointr Cloud . Upon client choice, Pointr Cloud either with or without encryption uses these values. Encryption enables device MAC identifier to be completely anonymous / impossible to trace. Persistence chart ¶ The following chart illustrates how data is stored in the Pointr Ecosystem SDK (iOS) SDK (Android) POP Persistent whilst SDK is installed? Yes Yes N/A (Independent of SDK) Persistent if SDK is uninstalled and re-installed? Subject to Apple API No N/A (Independent of SDK) Persistent upon every visit? Yes Yes Android - Yes iOS 8.0 and later - Yes if user connects to WiFi No otherwise Pre iOS 8.0 - Yes Traceable back to person? No (unless additional information is provided to SDK such as loyalty card number) No (unless additional information is provided to SDK such as loyalty card number) No (unless encryption is disabled and physically accessing device) Persistent upon SDK version upgrade? Yes Yes N/A (Independent of SDK) Persistent upon device OS upgrade? Yes Yes Yes Persistent if user switches to a different device? Subject to Apple API No No Summary of Data Storage on Pointr Cloud ¶ Users log into Pointr Cloud using their username and passwords. Once they are logged in, Pointr Cloud logs their activities among dashboards. Stored log activity data includes user Id, activity Id, activity result code (whether it was successful or not), activity result message, activity exception Summary Table of Data Storage between SDK and Pointr Cloud ¶ Type / Reason Description What’s stored Duration Logging/Backup Sensitive Information Position Data For Location Analytics Device position in venue or outside (when GPS is enabled) Indoor position (relative coordinates in store, timestamp, device id) Outdoor position (GPS coordinates, timestamp, device id) (Layer 1) 3 Months Monthly No (it’s not possible to link back to an actual user in most cases) Position Analytics For Location Analytics Heatmap, Visit sessions, Campaign messages, Zone analytics Reports generated based on Position information (Layer 2) 6 Months Monthly No SDK Analytics -For Pointr Mobile SDK telemetry and usage analytics_ Number of SDK sessions, Number of searches, Poi search content, Number of paths started Number of paths completed, Number of paths cancelled Relevant metrics, Device ID (Layer 3) 12 Months Monthly No Crash logs For inspecting any potential crashes in SDK Exception details including device hardware and software specs (such as operating system or device model) Crash reason, Crash type, Crash logs, Device model, Device OS version, Timestamp, CPU usage, Memory usage (Layer 1) 3 Months Monthly No Data Storage Between SDK and Pointr Cloud ¶ Registration ¶ When SDK begins, it creates a unique device identifier (per device and app - ie. same user on the same device using a different app will have a different identifier, or same user on a different device will also have a different identifier. Info In other words, this identifier is only useful when used in the same app-install by the same user, on the same device). This is what’s used to register and recognise this user. For more information, see notes about anonymous Device IDs above. Push Registration (Optional) ¶ This feature is managed by Push Manager in SDK. It assigns an authentication token to device by using device Identifier, which enables device to receive push notifications. This feature is optional, can be enabled/disabled based on client’s request. Analytics Upload ¶ This feature is managed by Analytics Manager in SDK. It is used in order to store analytic data, such as count of searched POIs, duration of session (time spent using SDK), count of path calculations, searched POIs and count of cancelled path calculations. No user Id or device Id is stored during this process. Position Upload ¶ This feature is managed by Location Sharing Manager in SDK. It is used in order to store position data of users. Along with x coordinate, y coordinate and level information, time stamp, user Id and device Identifier is stored in Pointr Cloud . Later on this position data is used to generate analytic charts such as Heatmap, Simulation, Tracking etc. Beacon Status Upload ¶ Pointr Mobile SDK includes Crowd Maintenance​, which allows venues to overview beacon status by their own users. Users upload beacon information as they browse the store. This feature is managed by Maintenance Manager in SDK. It is used in order to monitor health status of beacons. Battery level, hardware, firmware, beacon brand, advertisement power,beacon identifier, uuid, major value and minor values are uploaded to Pointr Cloud . Note Please note - this feature is highly optimised for battery and data bandwidth, to ensure users do not lose battery or use too much data for reporting. Reporting is done only once per session in aggregated format. This feature can be enabled/disabled based on client’s requirements. SDK Crash Log Upload ¶ This feature is managed by the Crash Handler in SDK. In case of a crash, Pointr SDK sends out the reason of crash, type of crash, call stack, a timestamp, and any related device information - such as application state, bluetooth state, cpu usage, battery level, model, platform and firmware version, etc. No user Id or device Id is stored during this process. Data Storage on Pointr Cloud (For Web Users Only) ¶ Users log into Pointr Cloud using their username and passwords. Once they are logged in, Pointr Cloud logs their activities among dashboards. Stored log activity data includes user Id, activity Id, activity result code (whether it was successful or not), activity result message, activity exception message (in case of a failure) and IP address of the user. Hint If you have any outstanding questions, please get in touch ! Your questions and feedback will help these documents to evolve

docs.text: Pointr Mobile SDK is a native mobile library, available for iOS and Android (at the time of this writing), designed to enable many features such as indoor positioning, indoor navigation, point of interest search and more. It is typically embedded into client mobile applications for enabling these features (rather than being served standalone). Pointr Mobile SDK supports offline functionality for all essential parts, however, it will synchronise with Pointr Cloud as necessary to carry out activities such as: Downloading latest venue content (maps, points of interest, navigation information, etc.) Uploading user device position (both cached and real-time) Uploading user analytics

Based on data gathered by POP devices , Pointr Cloud provides analytical reports on visits, durations and dwell times, and more.

docs.text: Logging ¶ Overview ¶ Pointr SDK has an internal logger mechanism, supporting different logging levels and automatically prevents too much logging in Production mode. Standard logging levels are supported Debug Verbose Info Warning Error Pointr SDK prints to console which logging levels are activated when it is started. 3 rd parties can alter logging level as they wish, via calling methods in Pointr / PointrBase class.
docs.title: Logging

docs.text: Pointr SDK has an internal logger mechanism, supporting different logging levels and automatically prevents too much logging in Production mode. Standard logging levels are supported Debug Verbose Info Warning Error Pointr SDK prints to console which logging levels are activated when it is started. 3 rd parties can alter logging level as they wish, via calling methods in Pointr / PointrBase class.
docs.title: Overview

docs.text: Pointr Managers ¶ Overview ¶ Pointr SDK is structured as a collection of individual components that act as standalone managers for various parts of the Pointr SDK . Managers are designed to be self-contained, and responsible for one aspect of the library, or a primary function (such as PositionManager being responsible for all position calculations). Managers can be turned on or off and each manager has a function that will allow you to start or stop the Manager’s operations. Pointr Managers ¶ Manager Description Position Manager contains all position calculation functionality Path Manager contains all pathfinding functionality Poi Manager contains all search and listing functionality for Poi’s Map Manager contains all map content functionality Data Manager manages all data synchronisation with bundle content as well as online content from Pointr Cloud Configuration Manager manages current configuration of the SDK Geofence Manager manages geofence enter / exit detections Accessing a Manager ¶ Managers are accessed through the main Pointr instance, such as: JAVA Pointr . getPointr (). getPositionManager (). getState ( this ); OBJECTIVE-C [[[ Pointr sharedInstance ] getPositionManager ] getState ]; In the vast majority of usecases, managers won’t require any extra configuration before they can be used Delegate - Listener pattern ¶ Pointr Mobile SDK makes heavy use of Delegates and Listeners to make it easy to access and react to valuable data from components without having to understand their functionality. As a result, Managers provide a specific Protocol or Interface to which other classes can Subscribe to. For example, the following code enables listener to be notified of all Poi Manager updates such as when Poi content gets updated. JAVA { ... //Subscribe to Poi Manager callbacks Pointr . getPoiManager . addListener ( this ); ... } OBJECTIVE-C { ... //Subscribe to Poi Manager callbacks [[[ Pointr sharedInstance ] getPoiManager ] addListener : self ]; ... }
docs.title: Pointr Managers

docs.text: Pointr Map modes ¶ Overview ¶ Five map modes are supported by default, as described below. You have full control over which is displayed (meaning you can allow lots of flexibility for your User), this is available in the Container classes on both iOS and Android. FREE MODE TRACKING MODE ROTATIONAL TRACKING MODE PATH TRACKING MODE 1) Free mode ¶ Users can browse the map freely. They can drag, zoom in/out, change levels on map and map will stay intact. 2) Free mode + Locate me button ¶ Users can browse the map freely; however, if user’s pin is still inside the map canvas, the map will slide back to centre itself around the User’s current position on the map. If the User drags enough to lose the pin from the map canvas, then map will not slide back, and will show a ‘Locate me’ button instead. Note on Free Modes and Level change… Only if the user physically changes a level, map will update to that level to show the new level for the user. In this mode, the User can switch to another level at anytime. 3) Tracking mode ¶ Map will track user by locking user position in the centre. In this mode, map stays static whilst user position pin rotates as device rotates. Note that if position calibration hasn’t happened and initial compass is disabled, then pin will show as a circle, without showing any orientation. 4) Tracking with rotation mode ¶ Identical to tracking mode, except, map rotates while user position pin stays static (looking upward). Note if user position is not calibrated, it is not feasible to rotate the map (since device orientation is not determined accurately). Therefore, it will act as (3) until calibration. Once position is calibrated, it will start rotating the map. 5) Path tracking mode ¶ Default option for pathfinding, regardless of user’s actual position or orientation, map is rotated to ensure path is always pointing upward. All map modes are now controlled externally, with minimal logic embedded inside MapView. This allows you to control map mode switching logic more fully.
docs.title: Pointr Map modes

docs.text: Supported Devices ¶ iOS ¶ We support all standard iOS Devices running iOS 8 and up , starting with the iPhone 4S but due to hardware quality, performance is vastly improved on later models. Android ¶ The Android ecosystem encompasses a lot more variation than iOS, as a result there Users could experience vastly different experiences than one-another. As with any software involving the use of hardware - some devices will simply not function as expected, so we encourage a lot of testing on the Android Platform with as many different devices as possible. To get a Blue dot, Android 4.3 (Jelly Bean) and later is required Sensors Required ¶ For expected accuracy and improved performance, the following is also required: Bluetooth BLE antennna Compass Gyroscope Magnometer Accelerometer etc… And we optionally require: barometric pressure detector etc… Tablet support ¶ Pointr SDK is designed to work on any device screen size, however the device will still need to have the required sensors to function​ correctly while using Pointr SDK. You may only have limited support and a reduced experience without the required dependencies ARCore For Enhanced Experience ¶ On ARCore supported devices avail of any available AR features that you have signed up for, the User must also have installed the latest version of ARCore from Google. You can learn how to request this here
docs.title: Supported Devices

docs.text: Venues And Facilities ¶ Overview ¶ Most SDK functionality requires a venue to be selected. For example, to list all Poi’s, SDK needs to know which venue and facility. Venue vs Facility ¶ Pointr system treats any physical location, with the following hierachy: item description Venue Campus where venue is located such as whole lot of a shopping mall or a whole airport Facility Buildings / Areas in the venue, which are shown as different maps. For example, different terminals at an airport (each with its own map, shown one at a time) or a shopping centre divided as public area and office area. Level Floor in each facility - eg. Ground floor of a shop. Venue Selection Logic ¶ By default, the ConfigurationManager will select a Venue according to the default logic, which is detailed below. If you would rather implememt your own strategy, simply change your configuration- To enable or disable Default Venue Selection optionally specify this in BaseConfiguration.json under the ​facilityConfiguration​ object. Force selection / de-selection can be done via ConfigurationManager.switchConfiguration methods. De-selection is done via selecting for INVALID_FACILITY​ constant (iOS) or null​ (Android) 1. Forced configuration ¶ If a venue / facility is force selected by 3 rd party, SDK will be configured for this venue / facility until this selection is removed. 2. Current facility ¶ Current facility is detected through device’s actual physical location (via Geofence Manager). This is an optional feature and can be disabled via Configuration. 3. Last used facility ¶ If 1 and 2 are not met, SDK will try to use last used facility on this device. 4. Default facility ¶ If 1 , 2 and 3 are not met, SDK will try to configure for a default facility, if specified. 5. Base configuration ¶ If no facility configuration can be found, SDK will use BaseConfiguration. if you’re seeing empty maps… Maps will only be shown once a facility is selected, so, if no facility is selected as the default then the SDK will start running but will display empty maps. Don’t worry, this is expected behaviour , check your configuration.
docs.title: Venues And Facilities

docs.text: How to: Change the look of a Given MapDrawable ¶ We don’t recommend doing this on a large scale, as it could be an expensive operation and a point of failure for your UI, but it is certainly possibly to change the look of any given MapDrawable as you desire Example (Given Poi) ¶ But in some cases, you might want to change a given object on the map, such as the ‘Blue Dot’. To do this, you should simply subscribe to the Map’s events, and when the Map Objects are being drawn, find the one you want to adjust and intercept it before it is drawn. Changing the drawable for a given Poi OBJECTIVE-C // Customise what view to return for each item drawn on map (eg. Pois, User pin) - ( UIView * ) mapView: ( PTRMapView * ) mapView viewForDrawable: ( id < PTRMapDrawable > ) drawable { // For example: Return a different Blue Dot pin // where the name for this drawable is `kPTRUserPinDrawableKey` if ([ drawable . identifier _isEqualToStringIgnoringCase : kPTRUserPinDrawableKey ]) { return [ YOUR_OWN_BLUE_DOT ]; } return [ super mapView : mapView viewForDrawable : drawable ]; }
docs.title: Pointr SDK Recipes

docs.text: We don’t recommend doing this on a large scale, as it could be an expensive operation and a point of failure for your UI, but it is certainly possibly to change the look of any given MapDrawable as you desire
docs.title: How to: Change the look of a Given MapDrawable

docs.text: But in some cases, you might want to change a given object on the map, such as the ‘Blue Dot’. To do this, you should simply subscribe to the Map’s events, and when the Map Objects are being drawn, find the one you want to adjust and intercept it before it is drawn. Changing the drawable for a given Poi OBJECTIVE-C // Customise what view to return for each item drawn on map (eg. Pois, User pin) - ( UIView * ) mapView: ( PTRMapView * ) mapView viewForDrawable: ( id < PTRMapDrawable > ) drawable { // For example: Return a different Blue Dot pin // where the name for this drawable is `kPTRUserPinDrawableKey` if ([ drawable . identifier _isEqualToStringIgnoringCase : kPTRUserPinDrawableKey ]) { return [ YOUR_OWN_BLUE_DOT ]; } return [ super mapView : mapView viewForDrawable : drawable ]; }
docs.title: Example (Given Poi)

docs.location: Guides/Pointr Mobile SDK/Pointr SDK How Tos/display-floor-selector.html
docs.text: How to: List All Floors ¶ A common feature for apps integrating Pointr SDK and mapping is to display an option that allows the user to browse other floors than the one they’re on. This gives users the ability to explore the site without having to physically go there - which is perfect for navigating to a room on another floor, or finding a particular restroom or some other place of interest to the User We would start by adding a UI component that allows us to input the level we want to go to: You can implement this any way you like, but we recommend keeping it simple. The concept is fairly straightforward, and the UI element that you implement should be intuitive to your User. You have a basic example of our implementation in your Sample App, where we use a UIPickerView in iOS and a set of buttons or a Spinner on Android, but all you really need to do is display the list of available levels and allow your user to select one of these, then tell the MapManager to update appropriately. Example ¶ See it in action… OBJECTIVE-C ... availableLevels = [[[ Pointr sharedInstance ] getMapManager ] availableLevels ]; ... // update level picker with available levels You would simply display as many levels as are returned here in your implemented level picker, and then use the value selected by the user to change the map: See it in action… OBJECTIVE-C ... availableLevels = [[[ Pointr sharedInstance ] getMapManager ] availableLevels ]; ... // update level picker with available levels Reference documentation is available here… (iOS) PTRMapManager:availableLevels (Android) MapManager#getLevelList()
docs.title: Display A Floor Selector

docs.location: Guides/Pointr Mobile SDK/Pointr SDK How Tos/draw-selected-poi-differently.html
docs.text: How to: Draw the Selected Poi differently on the Map ¶ To make the Map interactive and allow Users to get some actual use out of our Points of Interest, it makes sense to highlight these at appropriate times, such as when they have been selceted, either through Searching for a Poi, or through exploring the map and tapping on any Poi View. Example (Selected Poi) ¶ In the Sample app you will observe that the UI State will change to display the floor and highlight the Poi so that it is obvious, and also display some information about the Poi, so tht the User can be sure they have selected the correct one First of all, add a listener on the Poi Manager: firstly register a Listener OBJECTIVE-C PTRPoiManagerInterface * poiManager = [[ Pointr sharedInstance ] getPoiManager ]; [ poiManager addListener : self ]; Then in the onPoiManagerSelectedPoi callback we get the PTRPoiView object, and then call enlargePoiImage on the PTRPoiView object to make it more noticable to the User. Highlight the selected Poi OBJECTIVE-C - ( void ) onPoiManagerSelectedPoi: ( PTRPoiContainer * ) poiSelection { if ( ! [[[ Pointr sharedInstance ] getConfigurationManager ] getCurrentConfiguration ] . userInterfaceConfiguration . shouldEnlargeSelectedPoi ) { return ; } PTRPoi * selectedPoi = [ poiSelection getPoiList ]. firstObject ; if ( ! [ selectedPoi isKindOfClass :[ PTRPoi class ]] || ! selectedPoi ) { // get selected did not return a poi return ; } // shrink previous if exists if ( self . previousSelectedPoiView != nil ) { [ self deselectDrawablePointView : self . previousSelectedPoiView ]; } // enlarge a new selected poi PTRPoiView * enlarge = ( PTRPoiView * )[ self . mapView viewWithDrawable : selectedPoi ]; if ( enlarge && [ enlarge isKindOfClass :[ PTRPoiView class ]]) { PTRDispatchAsyncOnMainQueue ( ^ { [ enlarge enlargePoiImage ]; self . previousSelectedPoiView = enlarge ; }); } }
docs.title: Set A Poi as Selected

docs.location: Guides/Pointr Mobile SDK/Pointr SDK How Tos/filter-search-results.html
docs.text: How to: Filter Poi Search Results ¶ When the user is looking for a specific place, or doesn’t want to have to explore the your various maps to find a destination, search is very important. We allow searching based on key terms, exact matching, and tags - all of this is information about a Poi is configurable in your Pointr Cloud instance, and is then used by the PoiManager to facilitate User queries. Similar to the concept of providing the User a Level Selector, we suggest that custom Poi Search components are lept as lightweight UI objects, to allow a user to input search terms, and then a list structure to display the results, without being overly complicated or cluttering up the screen. A strategy might be to have a button that shows or hides your Search Component, or perhaps have it permanently display on the screen as in our Sample App. Example ¶ To call the Poi Manager and filter your search results, you should do something like this: See it in action… OBJECTIVE-C if ( self . searchTextField . text . length == 0 ) { // If no search query present if ( self . searchTextField . isFirstResponder ) { // Show the full list of Pois _resultContainer = [[ Pointr sharedInstance ] getPoiManager ]. getAllPoi ; // Load it into the search view as if we searched them _searchedPois = [ _resultContainer getPoiGroupList ]; } else { // If not selected and no query, do not show anything _resultContainer = nil ; _searchedPois = nil ; } } else { // if we have a query, lets do a search _resultContainer = [[[ Pointr sharedInstance ] getPoiManager ] searchPoi : self . searchTextField . text ]; // Search Pois based on the query _searchedPois = [ _resultContainer getPoiGroupList ]; } // now update our search view with our results ... Once a User selects a result, you will likely want to tell the MapManager to navigate to that floor, and then set the Poi we are looking for as the one Selected, and bring it into focus (see Drawing a Selected Poi differently on the Map ) below) Reference Documentation is available here… PoiManager - searchPoi PoiManager - searchPoi : inFacility :
docs.title: Filter Search Results

docs.location: Guides/Pointr Mobile SDK/Pointr SDK How Tos/map-content-update.html
docs.text: How to: Update a Map when there is a Content Update ¶ One of the reasons that Pointr SDK is easy to work with is that each Primary Component of the system is what we call a Pointr Manager , which is responsible for a Primary function of the SDK. Each Manager has a delegate protocol or interface with update callbacks in a standardised form (i.e., onXXXUpdated ) so that you can intuitively react to changing parts of the system. Say the Content is updated, or the User’s position is updated. We might want to reload what we display, or perhaps display something different altogether (like another map) In this case we’re interested specifically in the MapManagerDelegate or MapManagerListener , and to handle its events we simply listen to it like so: Example ¶ See it in action… OBJECTIVE-C ... MapManagerInterface * mapManager = [[ Pointr sharedInstance ] getPoiManager ]; [ mapManager addListener : self ]; ... JAVA ... MapManager mapManager = Pointr . getPointr (). getMapManager (); mapManager . addListener ( this ); ... When we want to react to a callback from a manager, specifically the MapManager in this case, we would implement onMapManagerMapUpdatedForVenue See it in action… OBJECTIVE-C - ( void ) onMapManagerMapUpdatedForVenue: ( int ) venueId facility: ( int ) facilityId level: ( int ) level mapType: ( PTRDataType ) mapType ... // In this example we are showing the first map displayed if ( ! self . mapView . isFirstMapShown ) { // As no maps loaded yet, set current level to this one [ self . mapView setCurrentLevel : level ]; } ...
docs.title: Update Map For Content Update

docs.text: How to: Show a Poi as Selected on the Map ¶ To facilitate a User Poi selection we need to add some code to the onViewTouched callback of the MapManager Example ¶ The example below is a little complex, but self explanatory - firstly we will ensure that it is visible by disallowing it from being hidden by the Pointr Poi Clash Algorithm See it in action… OBJECTIVE-C - ( void ) mapView: ( PTRMapView * ) mapView onViewTouched: ( nonnull UIView * ) view forDrawable: ( nonnull id < PTRMapDrawable > ) drawable { ... // if touched item is a poi set it as selected poi PTRPoi * touchedPoi = ( PTRPoi * ) drawable ; self . touchedDrawable = touchedPoi ; self . touchedDrawable . canBeHiddenWhenClashed = NO ; [[[ Pointr sharedInstance ] getPoiManager ] setSelectedPoiContainer :[ PTRPoiContainer . alloc initWithPoi : touchedPoi ]]; logv ( @"selected poi from map view : %@" , touchedPoi . name ); // zoom to selected poi float zoomTo = ( touchedPoi . maximumZoomLevel + touchedPoi . minimumZoomLevel ) / 2.0 ; [ self . mapView zoomViewToDrawable : touchedPoi zoomLevel : zoomTo ]; // set view state for poi selection [ self setViewState : PTRContainerViewStateMapWithPoiSelection ]; ... } Reference Documentation is available here… PoiManager setSelectedPoiContainer
docs.title: Set A Poi as Selected

docs.location: Guides/Pointr Mobile SDK/Pointr SDK How Tos/venue-content.html
docs.text: How to: Check for Venue Content ¶ Given the importance of Content in an App as visual and interactive as one that would use Pointr SDK, you will need to know when you have Content prepared for your app, so that you don’t try to display it too soon. You might have included your Content as Offline Content , in which case users will have the Content you distributed with the App Instance they have installed. However, keeping Content fresh and updated is important for appropriately engaging with your User While your app is starting up, you might have received a callback from a given manager, like the MapManager, and wish to start displaying your Pois and other Content. You shouldn’t do this without checking that the rest of the Content is ready first, and the way to do this is to ask the DataManager using the isContentReadyForVenue function. Example ¶ See it in action… OBJECTIVE-C ... // Check if venue content is ready, and send a callback if it is ready from a non-ready state if ([ self isContentReadyForVenue : venueId shouldAcceptRasterMapsAlso : acceptRasterMaps ]) { // Content is ready } else { // Content is not yet ready } ... This function will bascially check with the other important managers (Pois/Paths/Walls etc) and ensure they report a ready status before confirming tha App Content is ready. You can read more specifically about the DataManager functions and operations here , we offer lazy loading and automatic updates to make life easier for everyone. Hint As long as the device has had an internet connection at some point, Content will be updated, however we recommened checking with the DataManager every time you open the app, or as often as you feel comfortable, but you don’t have to keep doing this as Pointr SDK will try to keep itself up-to-date ???+ info “Reference Documentation is available here… - iOS PTRDataManager:isContentReadyForVenue:shouldAcceptRasterMapsAlso
docs.title: Check for Venue Content

docs.text: Prerequisites latest official version of Android Studio Pointr SampleApp project Pointr SDK Licence key Pointr Android Build Server username and API key Your Pointr Cloud endpoint One or more configurable beacons (optional) Pointr Cloud user credentials (optional) Step 1) Open provided PointrSample project using Android Studio. ¶ Typically the project is provided as a .zip file on a private Google Drive link. You will need to download the .zip file, extract it to any location on hard disk, then open it with Android Studio. Extract shared .zip file for PointrSample project Open the project using the ‘existing project’ option, pointing to the extracted folder Step 2) Populate all required fields in the project. ¶ Required Configuratuion files include the following: BaseConfiguration.json (under src/assets) ¶ Optional You can add up to 20 UUID’s here, following the JSON syntax. UUID’s entered here must match the UUID values of the beacons used. But note that at least one UUID is required for positioning to work ! Parameter Description Example sdkConfiguration.baseUrl Pointr Cloud instance URL “baseUrl”: “http://xxx.pointr.cloud” sdkConfiguration.uuidList UUID values of beacons { “uuidList”:[{ “index”: 0, “uuid”: “12345-…-ABCD” },{ “index”: 1, “uuid”:”12345-…-ABCD” },{ “index”: 2, “uuid”: “12345-…-AAAA” }] } venueConfiguration.venueName Name of the venue (more info in Venue vs Facility ) section “name”: “Joe’s London Venue” facilityConfiguration.name Name of the facility (more info in Venue vs Facility ) section “name”: “Joe’s Restaurant” Note After each change in BaseConfiguration.json, a fresh install is required. See Configuration for more information. strings.xml (under /res/values) ¶ A valid licence key is required for Pointr SDK to work. If device has no internet connection, SDK might allow to run for few times but it will eventually require a server connection and a valid licence key before letting the SDK begin. Parameter Description Example licence Pointr SDK licence <string name= "licence" tools:ignore= "TypographyDashes" > 12345678-4-1234-1234-123456789012 </string> build.gradle (under /src) ¶ You need to input Pointr library name and version to your module level build file Parameter Description Example LIBRARY_NAME The given name for your Pointr Library Flavour (this will be supplied to you by us) ‘pointr-demo’ LIBRARY_VERSION The given Version Number for the Pointr library you are currently using (this will be supplied to you by us) ‘3.5.0’ Example implementation ' com . pointrlabs : pointr - demo : 3.5.0 ' Build.gradle (project level) ¶ Finally, you need to input Pointr Android Build Server username and API key for Android Studio to automatically access the SDK. Info Ensure your internet connection allows access to port 8081 . On some enterprise networks, ports other than HTTP may be blocked on company firewall and may prevent you from accessing the library Step 3) Running the application ¶ If everything is setup correctly, you can now run the application. When run, the application will first go through Pointr States (refer to “Pointr States” section under “Starting Pointr SDK” chapter) then show an empty screen. If a facility is selected (refer to “Venue selection” chapter) and if device has good internet connection, SDK will start loading content (maps, Poi’s, etc.) from Pointr Cloud and display it on screen. Without beacons, you can only display the content and use SDK functions (eg. Poi search) but cannot see blue dot positioning yet. 4) Setup beacons to establish blue-dot positioning ¶ Info Pointr SDK requires BLE beacons to start positioning engine. One or more configured beacons are required! For demo purposes, we provide the following Major and Minor values for beacons to achieve indicated positions on a map. Notes on this Beacon configuration ​The UUIDs used can be changed via BaseConfiguration.json The map displayed can be changed , however map changes without configration updates will lead to relatively minor discrepancies in positioning Ensure 0 th level is used since these beacon values position on 0 th floor 5) Confirm bluedot, test Pathfinding, make something awesome ¶ By default, pathfinding requires a position for starting point. Once you have blue-dot, you can now click on or search for Poi’s to navigate to them. Info Pathfinding without an indoor position is also possible. SDK allows methods to navigate between any two arbitrary start / end points, however, the Pointr SDK Sample App only demonstrates pathfinding starting from the blue-dot indoor position. Next Steps View some demos Get started with Pointr Cloud tutorial Cookbook or recipes or tutorials for common actions Guide to debugging with the SampleApp Best Practice for Beacon Placement Generic Blog post plug

docs.text: Prerequisites latest official release of XCode Pointr SampleApp project Pointr SDK Licence key Pointr Cloud endpoint and, optionally: 1 or more beacons you can configure Pointr Cloud Access/Credentials 1) Import Pointr SampleApp to XCode ¶ Typically the project is provided as a .zip file on a private Google Drive link. You will need to download the .zip file, extract it to any location on hard disk, then open it with Xcode. Extract shared .zip file for SampleApp Xcode project 2) Populate the required configuration files ¶ Required Configuratuion files include the following: BaseConfiguration.json (can be found inside PointrContent.bundle) ¶ Optional You can add up to 20 UUID’s here, following the JSON syntax. UUID’s entered here must match the UUID values of the beacons used. But note that at least one UUID is required for positioning to work ! Parameter Description Example sdkConfiguration.baseUrl Pointr Cloud instance URL “baseUrl”: “http://xxx.pointr.cloud” sdkConfiguration.uuidList UUID values of beacons { “uuidList”:[{ “index”: 0, “uuid”: “12345-…-ABCD” },{ “index”: 1, “uuid”:”12345-…-ABCD” },{ “index”: 2, “uuid”: “12345-…-AAAA” }] } venueConfiguration.venueName Name of the venue (more info in [Venue vs Facility][venue-vs-facility]) section “name”: “Joe’s London Venue” facilityConfiguration.name Name of the facility (more info in [Venue vs Facility][venue-vs-facility]) section “name”: “Joe’s Restaurant” Warning After each change made to BaseConfiguration.json , a fresh install is required. See Configuration for more information. Licence key (inside AppDelegate.m) ¶ Info A valid licence key is required for Pointr SDK to work If device has no internet connection, the SDK will start a limited amount of times before eventually requiring a connection to validate the license. Parameter Description Example license Pointr SDK License Key NSString licenseKey = @”12345678-1234-1234-1234-123456789012”; 3) Running the Application ¶ If everything is setup correctly, you can now run the application! When you first run, the application will first go through Pointr States , and then present an empty screen. If a facility is selected (refer to Venue Selection and if device has good internet connection, SDK will start loading content (maps, Poi’s, etc.) from Pointr Cloud and display it on screen. Without beacons, you can only display the content and use SDK functions (eg. Poi search) but cannot see blue dot positioning yet. 4) Setup beacons to establish blue-dot positioning ¶ Info Pointr SDK requires BLE beacons to start positioning engine. One or more configured beacons are required! For demo purposes, we provide the following Major and Minor values for beacons to achieve indicated positions on a map. Notes on this Beacon configuration ​The UUIDs used can be changed via BaseConfiguration.json The map displayed can be changed , however map changes without configration updates will lead to relatively minor discrepancies in positioning Ensure 0 th level is used since these beacon values position on 0 th floor 5) Confirm bluedot, test Pathfinding, make something awesome ¶ By default, pathfinding requires a position for starting point. Once you have blue-dot, you can now click on or search for Poi’s to navigate to them Static Pathfinding Pathfinding without an indoor position is also possible. You can use the SDK to navigate between any two arbitrary start and end points on the map, however, the Pointr SDK SampleApp only demonstrates pathfinding starting from a “blue-dot” indoor position. Next Steps ¶ View some demos Get started with Pointr Cloud tutorial Cookbook or recipes or tutorials for common actions Guide to debugging with the SampleApp Best Practice for Beacon Placement Generic Blog post plug Tip Don’t forget - if you can’t still find what you’re looking for and you need some help, you can always for [get in touch][get-in-touch]
docs.title: Get started on iOS

docs.text: SaveList ¶ This function is used to save the Position data captured by beacons. SDK sends out a list of Positions and it is saved into database. It is used by default, uploads user position in relative coordinates (x, y, level) and facility id. Endpoint: ​ Listener/SaveList Input: ​List positionList__Position : Int FacilityId : id of the faclity where position is captured Long deviceTimestamp timestamp of the moment when position is captured Int pinX x coordinate that is calculated using only Bluetooth Int pinY y coordinate that is calculated using only Bluetooth Int pinLevel level that is calculated using only Bluetooth Int realX x coordinate that is calculated using Bluetooth and Fusion Int realY y coordinate that is calculated using Bluetooth and Fusion Int realLevel level that is calculated using Bluetooth and Fusion Int rotatitionDegrees rotation degrees String deviceIdentifier unique device Identifier of the user Int userId unique Id of user String userGroup group information of related user
docs.title: SaveList

docs.text: UploadBeaconStatus ¶ This function is used to save the health status of each beacon. Beacon status data is sent out at application start and when application is killed. These are captured and uploaded by MaintenanceManager in the SDK (when enabled). Endpoint​ : SdkAnalytics/UploadBeaconStatus Input : ​List beaconDataInfos, int? facilityId

docs.text: public class APIRequest extends Object ¶ Main object for creating any sort of Network Request. Class Constructors ¶ APIRequest() ¶ public APIRequest () Instantiates a new Api request. APIRequest(String requestUrl, ApiTypes.HttpMethodType methodType, ApiTypes.HttpTaskType taskType) ¶ public APIRequest ( String requestUrl , ApiTypes . HttpMethodType methodType , ApiTypes . HttpTaskType taskType ) Initialises a request object with no additional data. Parameters: requestUrl - The endpoint which the request will be sent to. methodType - Method Type taskType - Task Type APIRequest(String relativeUrl, Venue venue, Facility facility, String requestData, ApiTypes.HttpMethodType methodType, ApiTypes.HttpTaskType taskType) ¶ public APIRequest ( String relativeUrl , Venue venue , Facility facility , String requestData , ApiTypes . HttpMethodType methodType , ApiTypes . HttpTaskType taskType ) APIRequest(String endPoint, Integer facilityId, String requestData, ApiTypes.HttpMethodType methodType, ApiTypes.HttpTaskType taskType) ¶ public APIRequest ( String endPoint , Integer facilityId , String requestData , ApiTypes . HttpMethodType methodType , ApiTypes . HttpTaskType taskType ) Initialises a request object with no additional data. Parameters: endPoint - The endpoint which the request will be sent to. facilityId - The facility of the requested data. methodType - Method Type taskType - Task Type APIRequest(String requestUrl, String requestData, ApiTypes.HttpMethodType methodType, ApiTypes.HttpTaskType taskType) ¶ public APIRequest ( String requestUrl , String requestData , ApiTypes . HttpMethodType methodType , ApiTypes . HttpTaskType taskType ) Initialises a request object with data or session. Parameters: requestUrl - The endpoint which the request will be sent to. requestData - Additional data represented as NSData methodType - Method Type taskType - Task Type APIRequest(String requestUrl, String requestData, ApiTypes.HttpMethodType methodType, ApiTypes.HttpTaskType taskType, int facilityId) ¶ public APIRequest ( String requestUrl , String requestData , ApiTypes . docs.text: public class BluetoothCrashResolver extends Object ¶ This class provides relief for Android Bug 67272. This bug in the Bluedroid stack causes crashes in Android’s BluetoothService when scanning for BLE devices encounters a large number of unique devices. It is rare for most users but can be problematic for those with apps scanning for Bluetooth LE devices in the background (e.g. iBeacon-enabled apps), especially when these users are around Bluetooth LE devices that randomize their mac address like Gimbal beacons. This class can both recover from crashes and prevent crashes from happening in the first place More details on the bug can be found at the following URLs: https://code.google.com/p/android/issues/detail?id=67272 https://github.com/RadiusNetworks/android-ibeacon-service/issues/16 Version 1.0 Class Constructors ¶ BluetoothCrashResolver(android.content.Context context) ¶ public BluetoothCrashResolver ( android . content . Context context ) Constructor should be called only once per long-running process that does Bluetooth LE scanning. Must call start() to make it do anything. Parameters: context - the Activity or Service that is doing the Bluetooth scanning Class Methods ¶ crashDetected() ¶ public void crashDetected () Crash detected. disableDebug() ¶ public void disableDebug () Disable debug logging enableDebug() ¶ public void enableDebug () Enable debug logging. By default no debug lines are logged. forceFlush() ¶ public void forceFlush () Used to force a recovery operation getDetectedCrashCount() ¶ public int getDetectedCrashCount () Gets detected crash count. Returns: the detected crash count getLastBluetoothCrashDetectionTime() ¶ public long getLastBluetoothCrashDetectionTime () Gets last bluetooth crash detection time. Returns: the last bluetooth crash detection time getRecoveryAttemptCount() ¶ public int getRecoveryAttemptCount () Gets recovery attempt count. Returns: the recovery attempt count isLastRecoverySucceeded() ¶ public boolean isLastRecoverySucceeded () Is last recovery succeeded boolean. Returns: the boolean isRecoveryInProgress() ¶ public boolean isRecoveryInProgress () Is recovery in progress boolean. Returns: the boolean notifyScannedDevice(android.bluetooth.BluetoothDevice device, android.bluetooth.BluetoothAdapter.LeScanCallback scanner) ¶ public void notifyScannedDevice ( android . bluetooth . BluetoothDevice device , android . bluetooth . BluetoothAdapter . LeScanCallback scanner ) Call this method from your BluetoothAdapter.LeScanCallback method. Doing so is optional, but if you do, this class will be able to count the number of disctinct bluetooth devices scanned, and prevent crashes before they happen. This works very well if the app containing this class is the only one running bluetooth LE scans on the device, or it is constantly doing scans (e.g. is in the foreground for extended periods of time.) This will not work well if the application using this class is only scanning periodically (e.g. when in the background to save battery) and another application is also scanning on the same device, because this class will only get the counts from this application. Future augmentation of this class may improve this by somehow centralizing the list of unique scanned devices. Parameters: device - the device scanner - the scanner setUpdateNotifier(BluetoothCrashResolver.UpdateNotifier updateNotifier) ¶ public void setUpdateNotifier ( BluetoothCrashResolver . UpdateNotifier updateNotifier ) Sets update notifier. Parameters: updateNotifier - the update notifier start() ¶ public void start () Starts looking for crashes of the Bluetooth LE system and taking proactive steps to stop crashes from happening. Proactive steps require calls to notifyScannedDevice(Device device) so that crashes can be predicted ahead of time. stop() ¶ public void stop () Stops looking for crashes. Does not need to be called in normal operations, butmay be useful for testing.
docs.title: BluetoothCrashResolver

docs.text: This class provides relief for Android Bug 67272. This bug in the Bluedroid stack causes crashes in Android’s BluetoothService when scanning for BLE devices encounters a large number of unique devices. It is rare for most users but can be problematic for those with apps scanning for Bluetooth LE devices in the background (e.g. iBeacon-enabled apps), especially when these users are around Bluetooth LE devices that randomize their mac address like Gimbal beacons. This class can both recover from crashes and prevent crashes from happening in the first place More details on the bug can be found at the following URLs: https://code.google.com/p/android/issues/detail?id=67272 https://github.com/RadiusNetworks/android-ibeacon-service/issues/16 Version 1.0

docs.text: public void notifyScannedDevice ( android . bluetooth . BluetoothDevice device , android . bluetooth . BluetoothAdapter . LeScanCallback scanner ) Call this method from your BluetoothAdapter.LeScanCallback method. Doing so is optional, but if you do, this class will be able to count the number of disctinct bluetooth devices scanned, and prevent crashes before they happen. This works very well if the app containing this class is the only one running bluetooth LE scans on the device, or it is constantly doing scans (e.g. is in the foreground for extended periods of time.) This will not work well if the application using this class is only scanning periodically (e.g. when in the background to save battery) and another application is also scanning on the same device, because this class will only get the counts from this application. Future augmentation of this class may improve this by somehow centralizing the list of unique scanned devices. Parameters: device - the device scanner - the scanner
docs.title: notifyScannedDevice(android.bluetooth.BluetoothDevice device, android.bluetooth.BluetoothAdapter.LeScanCallback scanner)

docs.text: public class FacilityConfiguration extends Object implements java.io.Serializable ¶ This configuration holds the configurable items for facilities. They can be set via BaseConfiguration.json or through PointrCloud. The values of these items can be modified at any time by changing the ¶ value on PointrCloud and the SDK will fetch the updated configuration, forcing the new value throughout the SDK. The items regarding the latitude and longitude are world coordinates of the physical map of the facility, which is a square. These values are used to convert Pointr coordinates to world coordinates. ##### If third party wants to get the latitude and longitude values of user position calculated by the Pointr Engine, it needs to give valid values to the latitudeTopLeft , longitudeTopLeft ,… Class Constructors ¶ FacilityConfiguration() ¶ public FacilityConfiguration () FacilityConfiguration(int internalIdentifier, String docs.text: public class VenueConfiguration extends Object implements java.io.Serializable ¶ This configuration holds the configurable items of Venues Integer internalIdentifier : the identifier used internally inside the SDK String externalIdentifier : the identifier that the third parties can set this to match their own systems id’s String name : the name of the venue String beaconType : the type of the beacon. The beacon decrypting API’s will differ depending on this value. (e.g. ‘kontakt’, ‘lookup’, etc.) Class Constructors ¶ VenueConfiguration() ¶ public VenueConfiguration () VenueConfiguration(int internalIdentifier, String externalIdentifier, String name, String beaconType) ¶ public VenueConfiguration ( int internalIdentifier , String externalIdentifier , String name , String beaconType ) Class Methods ¶ copy() ¶ public VenueConfiguration copy () equals(Object o) ¶ public boolean equals ( Object o ) Overrides: equals in class Object getBeaconType() ¶ public String getBeaconType () getExternalIdentifier() ¶ public String getExternalIdentifier () getInternalIdentifier() ¶ public Integer getInternalIdentifier () getName() ¶ public String getName () hashCode() ¶ public int hashCode () Overrides: hashCode in class Object merge(VenueConfiguration venueConfiguration) ¶ public void merge ( VenueConfiguration venueConfiguration ) setBeaconType(String beaconType) ¶ public void setBeaconType ( String beaconType ) setExternalIdentifier(String externalIdentifier) ¶ public void setExternalIdentifier ( String externalIdentifier ) setInternalIdentifier(Integer internalIdentifier) ¶ public void setInternalIdentifier ( Integer internalIdentifier ) setName(String name) ¶ public void setName ( String name ) toString() ¶ public String toString () Overrides: toString in class Object

docs.text: public class ObjectFactory extends T> ¶ This class is a general purpose “Object Factory”. Class Constructors ¶ ObjectFactory() ¶ public ObjectFactory () Class Methods ¶ clearClassMap() ¶ public static void clearClassMap () This method clears the class to class map. clearObjectMap() ¶ public static void clearObjectMap () This method clears the class to object map. invokeConstructor(reflect.Constructor constructor, Object[] args) ¶ public static < T > T invokeConstructor ( reflect . Constructor < T > constructor , Object [] args ) Invokes the given constructor with the given arguments, and returns the resulting object. It does not perform any checks to the given constructor and objects. If an exception is thrown, this method will throw an Error instead. The idea here is that if we fail object instantiation we should better fail and fail fast. Type Parameters: T - The type of the object being constructed. Parameters: constructor - The constructor args - Arguments to be passed to the constructor. Returns: the new object isClassMappedToObject(Class<?> clazz) ¶ public static boolean isClassMappedToObject ( Class <?> clazz ) Returns whether the given class is already mapped to an object. Parameters: clazz - the class to be checked for mapping. Returns: true if the class is mapped to an object, false otherwise. isCompatible(reflect.Constructor constructor, Object[] args) ¶ public static < T > boolean isCompatible ( reflect . Constructor < T > constructor , Object [] args ) Determine whether the given argument list args can be used to invoke the given constructor. Type Parameters: T - The type the constructor will construct. Parameters: constructor - the constructor args - the arguments that would be passed to the constructor Returns: true if the constructor can be invoked, false otherwise mapClassToClass(Class clazz1, Class<? extends T> clazz2) ¶ public static < T > void mapClassToClass ( Class < T > clazz1 , Class <? extends T > clazz2 ) This method causes clazz1 to be mapped to clazz2 so that when an instance of clazz1 is requested using the newObject() method, an instance of clazz2 will actually be generated. clazz2 must be a subclass of clazz1, or in case clazz1 is actually an interface, clazz2 must implement clazz1. Note that the mapping done here is not recursive. If you map a to b, and then map b to c, a request for a will not generate c, it will just generate b. Type Parameters: T - The type of clazz1 Parameters: clazz1 - the class mapped from clazz2 - the class mapped to mapClassToObject(Class clazz, T object) ¶ public static < T > void mapClassToObject ( Class < T > clazz , T object ) This method causes clazz to be mapped to a specific given object. When an instance of clazz is requested using the newObject() method, the given object will be returned. Note that this effectively causes the object to be a singleton, unless the mapping is modified on-the-fly. This is essentially meant for two cases: The object is difficult to construct, or should not be constructed by the callers for some reason or another. For testing purposes, one wishes to use mock objects with different settings for different tests. One can either modify the mapping to achieve this effect, or hold on to the reference and make the modifications directly on the mapped object. Type Parameters: T - The type of the object to be mapped Parameters: clazz - the class to be mapped from object - the object to be mapped to mapObjectClassToObject(Object object) ¶ public static void mapObjectClassToObject ( Object object ) This method puts object to classToObjectMap. While adding this object Parameters: object - object to be put into map newObject(Class<? extends T> clazz, Object… arguments) ¶ public static < T > T newObject ( Class <? extends T > clazz , Object ... arguments ) Construct a new object of the given type, using the given argument list as arguments to its constructor. This is the “main” method of the ObjectFactory class. The idea is, you need an instance of a class, and instead of using the new operator, you call this method, essentially with the same arguments. Why then? The point is, this method can give you an instance of a subclass instead of the original class if that class has been previously mapped to another class by a call to mapClassToClass method. In this way, it is possible to modify behavior – for instance it would be easy to insert mocks instead of the actual objects in this way. Another use case is like a “regular” factory. You can ask for an instance of an interface rather than a class using exactly the same semantics. In this case of course, it is mandatory to have the interface class mapped to an actual class before this call is made. Addendum: There is a special case. If the given class is mapped directly to an object, using the mapClassToObject method, that object is returned directly without considering any class mappings which may be made for that class. Type Parameters: T - the type of the object to be instantiated Parameters: clazz - the class (may be a class or an interface) of the object to be instantiated arguments - the arguments to the constructor Returns: the constructed object instance reset() ¶ public static void reset () & Reset the ObjectFactory. This will remove all mappings, effectively erasing all state from the ObjectFactory. This should not be used unless it is for testing purposes! unMapObject(Class<? extends T> clazz) ¶ public static < T > void unMapObject ( Class <? extends T > clazz )

docs.text: public static < T > T newObject ( Class <? extends T > clazz , Object ... arguments ) Construct a new object of the given type, using the given argument list as arguments to its constructor. This is the “main” method of the ObjectFactory class. The idea is, you need an instance of a class, and instead of using the new operator, you call this method, essentially with the same arguments. Why then? The point is, this method can give you an instance of a subclass instead of the original class if that class has been previously mapped to another class by a call to mapClassToClass method. In this way, it is possible to modify behavior – for instance it would be easy to insert mocks instead of the actual objects in this way. Another use case is like a “regular” factory. You can ask for an instance of an interface rather than a class using exactly the same semantics. In this case of course, it is mandatory to have the interface class mapped to an actual class before this call is made. Addendum: There is a special case. If the given class is mapped directly to an object, using the mapClassToObject method, that object is returned directly without considering any class mappings which may be made for that class. Type Parameters: T - the type of the object to be instantiated Parameters: clazz - the class (may be a class or an interface) of the object to be instantiated arguments - the arguments to the constructor Returns: the constructed object instance
docs.title: newObject(Class<? extends T> clazz, Object... arguments)

docs.text: public interface Poly ¶ The interface Poly. Class Methods ¶ add(Point p) ¶ void add ( Point p ) Add a point to the first inner polygon. Parameters: p - the p add(Poly p) ¶ void add ( Poly p ) Add an inner polygon to this polygon - assumes that adding polygon does not have any inner polygons. Parameters: p - the p add(double x, double y) ¶ void add ( double x , double y ) Add a point to the first inner polygon. Parameters: x - the x y - the y clear() ¶ void clear () Remove all of the points. Creates an empty polygon. difference(Poly p) ¶ Poly difference ( Poly p ) Return a Poly that is the difference of this polygon with the given polygon. The returned polygon could be complex. Parameters: p - the p Returns: the poly getArea() ¶ double getArea () Return the area of the polygon in square units. Returns: the area getBounds() ¶ Rectangle2D getBounds () Returns the bounding rectangle of this polygon. Returns: the bounds getInnerPoly(int polyIndex) ¶ Poly getInnerPoly ( int polyIndex ) Returns the polygon at this index. Parameters: polyIndex - the poly index Returns: the inner poly getNumInnerPoly() ¶ int getNumInnerPoly () Returns the number of inner polygons - inner polygons are assumed to return one here. Returns: the num inner poly getNumPoints() ¶ int getNumPoints () Return the number points of the first inner polygon Returns: the num points getX(int index) ¶ double getX ( int index ) Return the X value of the point at the index in the first inner polygon Parameters: index - the index Returns: the x getY(int index) ¶ double getY ( int index ) Return the Y value of the point at the index in the first inner polygon Parameters: index - the index Returns: the y intersection(Poly p) ¶ Poly intersection ( Poly p ) Return a Poly that is the intersection of this polygon with the given polygon. The returned polygon could be complex. Parameters: p - the p Returns: the poly isContributing(int polyIndex) ¶ boolean isContributing ( int polyIndex ) Return true if the given inner polygon is contributing to the set operation. This method should NOT be used outside the Clip algorithm. Parameters: polyIndex - the poly index Returns: the boolean isEmpty() ¶ boolean isEmpty () Return true if the polygon is empty Returns: the boolean isHole() ¶ boolean isHole () Return true if this polygon is a hole. Holes are assumed to be inner polygons of a more complex polygon. Returns: the boolean Throws: IllegalStateException - if called on a complex polygon. setContributing(int polyIndex, boolean contributes) ¶ void setContributing ( int polyIndex , boolean contributes ) Set whether or not this inner polygon is constributing to the set operation. This method should NOT be used outside the Clip algorithm. Parameters: polyIndex - the poly index contributes - the contributes setIsHole(boolean isHole) ¶ void setIsHole ( boolean isHole ) Set whether or not this polygon is a hole. Cannot be called on a complex polygon. Parameters: isHole - the is hole Throws: IllegalStateException - if called on a complex polygon. union(Poly p) ¶ Poly union ( Poly p ) Return a Poly that is the union of this polygon with the given polygon. The returned polygon could be complex. Parameters: p - the p Returns: the poly xor(Poly p) ¶ Poly xor ( Poly p ) Return a Poly that is the exclusive-or of this polygon with the given polygon. The returned polygon could be complex. Parameters: p - the p Returns: the poly

docs.text: public interface LocationSharingManager ¶ Main class for location sharing management The location sharing is done through this manager. The structure of sharing is, one user starts sharing location and enters recipients to receive the generated token for the session he started. The recipients then subscribe to the token they receive, and start location sharing. The location sharing session can be either receive, share, or both. The token shared has an indication of which type of location sharing session it starts. The external user Id can be set to change the alias used while sharing location. Class Methods ¶ addListener(LocationSharingManagerImpl.LocationSharingManagerListener listener) ¶ void addListener ( LocationSharingManagerImpl . LocationSharingManagerListener listener ) getAssetLocations(String assetIdentifier, boolean isGroup, long maxAgeInSeconds, GetLocationFromCppCallback getLocationFromCppCallback) ¶ void getAssetLocations ( String assetIdentifier , boolean isGroup , long maxAgeInSeconds , GetLocationFromCppCallback getLocationFromCppCallback ) Gets the location of the asset with the given identifier Parameters: assetIdentifier - The identifier of the asset isGroup - Specifies if the assets are grouped or not maxAgeInSeconds - Specifies the range of time to acquire the asset locations (e.g if “now = t sec” and “maxAgeInSeconds = 500 sec”, assets that were uploaded at most “t - 500 seconds” ago will be retrieved) getLocationFromCppCallback - GetLocationFromCppCallback getAssets(GetAssetsFromCppCallback getAssetsFromCppCallback, long maxAgeInSeconds) ¶ void getAssets ( GetAssetsFromCppCallback getAssetsFromCppCallback , long maxAgeInSeconds ) Gets the assets Parameters: getAssetsFromCppCallback - Callback that returns a list of Identifier pairs corresponding to assets maxAgeInSeconds - Specifies the range of time to acquire the assets (e.g if “now = t sec” and “maxAgeInSeconds = 500 sec”, assets that were uploaded at most “t - 500 seconds” ago will be retrieved) getLocations(LocationSharingPeerType peerType, long maxAgeInSeconds, GetLocationFromCppCallback getLocationFromCppCallback) ¶ void getLocations ( LocationSharingPeerType peerType , long maxAgeInSeconds , GetLocationFromCppCallback getLocationFromCppCallback ) Gets the locations of the subscribed peerType Parameters: peerType - This can be Group(1), Geofence(2), All(3) maxAgeInSeconds - Specifies the range of time to acquire the positions (e.g if “now = t sec” and “maxAgeInSeconds = 500 sec”, locations of other users that were uploaded at most “t - 500 seconds” ago will be retrieved) getLocationFromCppCallback - Callback that returns a list of OnlineLocation objects getSubscribers(GetSubscribersFromCppCallback subscribersFromCppCallback) ¶ void getSubscribers ( GetSubscribersFromCppCallback subscribersFromCppCallback ) Returns the subscribers to the user from the callback Parameters: subscribersFromCppCallback - Callback that returns a list of LocationSharingSubscriberData onPushManagerNotification(String message, String type) ¶ void onPushManagerNotification ( String message , String type ) removeListener(LocationSharingManagerImpl.LocationSharingManagerListener listener) ¶ void removeListener ( LocationSharingManagerImpl . LocationSharingManagerListener listener ) setExternalUserId(String userId) ¶ void setExternalUserId ( String userId ) start() ¶ void start () Main start method for LocationSharingManager. Starts location sharing. startSharingSession(String alias, long durationInSeconds, SessionSharingCallback callback, LocationSharingNotificationType notificationType, LocationSharingDirection direction, List recipients) ¶ void startSharingSession ( String alias , long durationInSeconds , SessionSharingCallback callback , LocationSharingNotificationType notificationType , LocationSharingDirection direction , List < String > recipients ) Starts location sharing session Parameters: alias - name of sharing party durationInSeconds - token validity duration callback - callback to session sharing result notificationType - LocationSharingNotificationType direction - LocationSharingDirection recipients - shared location receivers stop() ¶ void stop () Stops all the processes regarding LocationSharingManager stopSharingSession(String token) ¶ void stopSharingSession ( String token ) Stops sharing session with the given token Parameters: token - subscribe(String token, String alias, LocationSharingPeerType peerType) ¶ void subscribe ( String token , String alias , LocationSharingPeerType peerType ) Subscribes to location sharing token The only time token is necessary is if the peerType is Group. Else it automatically subscribes to wanted peertypes Parameters: token - This is the token to subscribe to alias - This will be the alias set for the current session of location sharing peerType - This can be Group(1), Geofence(2), All(3) unsubscribe(String token, LocationSharingPeerType type) ¶ void unsubscribe ( String token , LocationSharingPeerType type ) Unsubscribes from token. If the LocationSharingPeerType is Group, token is necessary or else any argument can be given as token and it will unsubscribe from the location sharing session Parameters: token - This is the token to unsubscribe from type - This can be Group(1), Geofence(2), All(3) updateConfiguration(LocationSharingManagerImpl.PTRLocationSharingManagerConfiguration configuration) ¶ void updateConfiguration ( LocationSharingManagerImpl . PTRLocationSharingManagerConfiguration configuration ) Updates configuration Parameters: configuration -
docs.title: LocationSharingManager

The structure of sharing is, one user starts sharing location and enters recipients to receive the generated token for the session he started. The recipients then subscribe to the token they receive, and start location sharing. The location sharing session can be either receive, share, or both. The token shared has an indication of which type of location sharing session it starts. The external user Id can be set to change the alias used while sharing location.

Bitmap getMapTileImage ( int level , Integer ... arguments ) Access method for the specified tile Parameters: level - Integer value for level arguments - Every integer you pass to the function will represent a tile property These properties are zoom level, row and column (values are in order) Returns: bitmap map tile image getMapVersionForFacility(Facility facility, int level) ¶ MapVersion getMapVersionForFacility ( Facility facility , int level ) MapProperties for the specified level Parameters: level - Integer value for level Returns: properties MapVersion hasContentForFacility(Facility currentFacility, boolean shouldAcceptRasterMapAlso) ¶ boolean hasContentForFacility ( Facility currentFacility , boolean shouldAcceptRasterMapAlso ) Checks whether the map content is present & ready for usage for the given facility Parameters: currentFacility - shouldAcceptRasterMapAlso - If true, either raster or tile maps are accepted as content. If false, tile maps are required to assume a venue’s maps are ready Returns: true if has content, false if not hasContentForVenue(Venue venue, boolean shouldAcceptRasterMapAlso) ¶ boolean hasContentForVenue ( Venue venue , boolean shouldAcceptRasterMapAlso ) Checks whether the map content is present & ready for usage for given venue Parameters: venue - shouldAcceptRasterMapAlso - If true, either raster or tile maps are accepted as content. docs.text: public interface PoiManager extends PointrManager, Advertiser ¶ Main class responsible for POI related search and access. Class Methods ¶ getAllPoi() ¶ PoiContainer getAllPoi () Returns all Poi objects. Sorted alphabetically ignoring case by title. Note there might be multiple Poi objects with same title. Returns: the all poi PoiContainer getAllPoi(Integer level, String type, Integer facilityId) ¶ PoiContainer getAllPoi ( Integer level , String type , Integer facilityId ) Returns all Poi objects. Sorted alphabetically ignoring case by title. Note there might be multiple Poi objects with same title. Parameters: level - indicates the level of poi’s returned if non-null. type - indicates the type of poi’s returned if non-null. facilityId - indicates the facility id of poi’s returned if non-null. Returns: the all poi PoiContainer getAllPoi(String… poiTypes) ¶ PoiContainer getAllPoi ( String ... poiTypes ) Returns all Poi objects with specified type. Sorted alphabetically ignoring case by title. Note there might be multiple Poi objects with same title. Nil is returned if no Poi is found with specified type or a non-existent type is specified. Parameters: poiTypes - the poi types, String var arguments, can give multiple types Returns: the all poi PoiContainer getAllPoiTypes() ¶ List < String > getAllPoiTypes () Returns all unique types of all Poi’s in the system. Returns nil of no poi exists. Sorts alphabetically by default. Returns: the all poi types getPoi(String identifier) ¶ Poi getPoi ( String identifier ) Gets poi. Parameters: identifier - the identifier Returns: the poi Poi getSelectedPoi() ¶ PoiContainer getSelectedPoi () Retrieves users Poi selection Returns: RequestedPoi object. PoiContainer getStoreLayoutPoi(int level) ¶ Poi getStoreLayoutPoi ( int level ) Parameters: level - level Returns: Poi With regionArray Poi hasContentForVenue(Venue venue) ¶ boolean hasContentForVenue ( Venue venue ) Checks whether the Poi content is present & ready for the given venue resetSelectedPoi() ¶ void resetSelectedPoi () Note This does not cancel navigation. This solely resets the cached Poi selection in this manager. searchPoi(String searchString) ¶ PoiContainer searchPoi ( String searchString ) Returns list of PTRPoi objects that match the given search string. Search is done on single word typically and is case insensitive. If more than one word is supplied, an OR search is performed using every word. Sorted alphabetically ignoring case by title. Parameters: searchString - the search string Returns: the requested poi PoiContainer setSelectedPoi(PoiContainer poiSelection) ¶ void setSelectedPoi ( PoiContainer poiSelection ) Marks user’s Poi selection which is typically used as destination in navigation Note Selecting a Poi resets Poi Group selection (if any) Parameters: poiSelection - the poiSelection

Parameters: level - indicates the level of poi’s returned if non-null. type - indicates the type of poi’s returned if non-null. facilityId - indicates the facility id of poi’s returned if non-null. Returns: the all poi PoiContainer
docs.title: getAllPoi(Integer level, String type, Integer facilityId)

docs.text: PoiContainer getAllPoi ( String ... poiTypes ) Returns all Poi objects with specified type. Sorted alphabetically ignoring case by title. Note there might be multiple Poi objects with same title. Nil is returned if no Poi is found with specified type or a non-existent type is specified. Parameters: poiTypes - the poi types, String var arguments, can give multiple types Returns: the all poi PoiContainer
docs.title: getAllPoi(String... poiTypes)

docs.text: List < String > getAllPoiTypes () Returns all unique types of all Poi’s in the system. Returns nil of no poi exists. Sorts alphabetically by default. Returns: the all poi types
docs.title: getAllPoiTypes()

docs.text: Poi getPoi ( String identifier ) Gets poi. Parameters: identifier - the identifier Returns: the poi Poi
docs.title: getPoi(String identifier)

docs.text: PoiContainer getSelectedPoi () Retrieves users Poi selection Returns: RequestedPoi object. PoiContainer
docs.title: getSelectedPoi()

docs.text: Poi getStoreLayoutPoi ( int level ) Parameters: level - level Returns: Poi With regionArray Poi
docs.title: getStoreLayoutPoi(int level)

docs.text: boolean hasContentForVenue ( Venue venue ) Checks whether the Poi content is present & ready for the given venue
docs.title: hasContentForVenue(Venue venue)

docs.text: void resetSelectedPoi () Note This does not cancel navigation. This solely resets the cached Poi selection in this manager.
docs.title: resetSelectedPoi()

docs.text: PoiContainer searchPoi ( String searchString ) Returns list of PTRPoi objects that match the given search string. Search is done on single word typically and is case insensitive. If more than one word is supplied, an OR search is performed using every word. Sorted alphabetically ignoring case by title. Parameters: searchString - the search string Returns: the requested poi PoiContainer
docs.title: searchPoi(String searchString)

docs.text: void setSelectedPoi ( PoiContainer poiSelection ) Marks user’s Poi selection which is typically used as destination in navigation Note Selecting a Poi resets Poi Group selection (if any) Parameters: poiSelection - the poiSelection
docs.title: setSelectedPoi(PoiContainer poiSelection)

docs.text: public interface PushManager ¶ Main manager class responsible for push related registration and handling. Class Methods ¶ registerAppForPush(PushManagerCallback callback) ¶ void registerAppForPush ( PushManagerCallback callback ) Must be called to register app for push. This will prompt user with ‘App wants to send you notifications’ dialogue. Note This is called internally. Do not call. Parameters: callback - the callback PushManagerCallback registerPushToken(String deviceToken, PushTokenRegistrationCallback callback) ¶ void registerPushToken ( String deviceToken , PushTokenRegistrationCallback callback ) Registers the device into Pointr Database with the required user and device information. Parameters: deviceToken - Unique ID of the device to register for push. callback - Asynchronous callback block with the server response.
