docs.text: PTRPoiManagerInterface ¶ Inherits from PTRPointrManagerInterface Conforms to < > PTRPoiManagerDelegate id Declared in PTRPoiManagerInterface.h Overview ¶ Main interface to manage accessing Poi content Instance Methods ¶ getAllPoi ¶ Returns all Poi objects in current venue. Sorted alphabetically ignoring case by title. Note there might be multiple Poi objects with the same title. - ( PTRPoiContainer * _Nullable ) getAllPoi Returns: All pois getAllPoiTypes ¶ Returns all Poi’s types. - ( NSArray < NSString *> * _Nullable ) getAllPoiTypes Returns: array of poi type strings getAllPoisOnLevel:withType:inFacility: ¶ Returns all Poi objects, matching provided criteria, in current venue. Null criteria are ignored. Sorted alphabetically ignoring case by title. Note there might be multiple Poi objects with the same title. - ( PTRPoiContainer * ) getAllPoisOnLevel: ( NSNumber * _Nullable ) * level * withType :( NSString * _Nullable ) * type * inFacility :( NSNumber * _Nullable ) * facilityId * getPoiByName: ¶ Returns all Poi’s with given name, in current venue. - ( PTRPoiContainer * ) getPoiByName: ( NSString * ) * name * getPoiWithIdentifier: ¶ Returns Poi object with specified identifier. - ( PTRPoiContainer * ) getPoiWithIdentifier: ( NSString * ) * identifier * Parameters: identifier specifying the Poi. getSelectedPoi ¶ Retrieves users Poi selection - ( PTRPoiContainer * _Nullable ) getSelectedPoi Returns: RequestedPoi object. getStoreLayoutPoiForLevel:forFacility: ¶ Method which returns a poi with regionArray which shows the area of store to show - ( id < PTRRegionMapDrawable > ) getStoreLayoutPoiForLevel: ( int ) * level * forFacility :( int ) * facilityId * Parameters: level level facilityId facilityID Returns: drawable with regionArray hasContentForVenue: ¶ Checks whether the POI content is present & ready for the given venue It expects at least one POI to return true - ( BOOL ) hasContentForVenue: ( int ) * venueId * Parameters: venueId int venue id Returns: BOOL POI content is ready for the given venue resetSelectedPoiContainer ¶ Resets user’s selected Poi Warning This does not cancel navigation. This solely resets the cached Poi selection in this manager. - ( void ) resetSelectedPoiContainer searchPoi: ¶ Returns PTRPoiContainer that match the given search string. Search is done on single word typically and is case insensitive. If more than one word is supplied, an OR search is performed using every word. Sorted alphabetically ignoring case by title. - ( PTRPoiContainer * _Nullable ) searchPoi: ( NSString * ) * searchString * Parameters: searchString the search string Returns: the requested poi searchPoi:inFacility: ¶ Returns PTRPoiContainer that match the given search string. Search is done on single word typically and is case insensitive. If more than one word is supplied, an OR search is performed using every word. Sorted alphabetically ignoring case by title. - ( PTRPoiContainer * ) searchPoi: ( NSString * ) * searchString * inFacility :( int ) * facilityId * Parameters: searchString the search string facilityId the facility in which the search will done Returns: the requested poi setSelectedPoiContainer: ¶ Marks user’s Poi selection which is typically used as destination in navigation - ( void ) setSelectedPoiContainer: ( PTRPoiContainer * ) * poiSelection * Parameters: poiSelection the poiSelection

docs.text: PTRPushManagerInterface ¶ Inherits from PTRPointrManagerInterface Conforms to < > PTRPushManagerDelegate id Declared in PTRPushManagerInterface.h Overview ¶ Main manager class responsible for push related registration and handling. Instance Methods ¶ handleNotificationWithUserInfo: ¶ Parses the received push information in order to create a presentable notification. - ( BOOL ) handleNotificationWithUserInfo: ( NSDictionary * ) * userInfo * Parameters: userInfo Information received regarding push as a dictionary. Returns: A value indicating whether the notification handled properly(true) or not(false). playSoundForPush: ¶ Plays system sound (only if app is in foreground). - ( void ) playSoundForPush: ( int ) * inSystemSoundId * Parameters: inSystemSoundId ID of system sound to be played. Defaults to regular push notification sound if negative value given. registerAppForPush ¶ Must be called to register app for push. This will prompt user with ‘App wants to send you notifications’ dialogue. Warning This is called internally. Do not call. - ( void ) registerAppForPush registerPushToken:withCallback: ¶ Registers the device into Pointr Database with the required user and device information. - ( void ) registerPushToken: ( NSData * ) * deviceToken * withCallback :( void ( ^ ) ( PTRApiResponse * )) * callback * Parameters: deviceToken Unique ID of the device to register for push. callback Asynchronous callback block with the server response. setNotificationBadgeToValue: ¶ Sets the badge number representing the number of notifications. - ( void ) setNotificationBadgeToValue: ( int ) * badgeNumber * Parameters: badgeNumber Number within the badge to be shown on the application. unregisterUserFromPushwithCallback: ¶ Un-Registers user from Pointr related notifications and callback. - ( void ) unregisterUserFromPushwithCallback: ( void ( ^ ) ( PTRApiResponse * )) * callback * Parameters: callback Response callback returned from server.

docs.text: PTRUserManagerInterface ¶ Inherits from PTRPointrManagerInterface Conforms to < > PTRUserManagerDelegate id Declared in PTRUserManagerInterface.h Overview ¶ Main class responsible for user sessions, registration and login. Properties ¶ currentUserSession ¶ currentUserSession Returns current user session (if any) or nil @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) PTRUserSession * currentUserSession Instance Methods ¶ logoutWithCallback: ¶ Logs out current user and resets user session accordingly. - ( void ) logoutWithCallback: ( void ( ^ ) ( PTRApiResponse * )) * callback * Parameters: callback Asynchrnous block which will be returned along with server response regarding logout. registerDeviceWithCallback: ¶ Registers the device with anonymous user. (Works with no knowledge of user.) - ( void ) registerDeviceWithCallback: ( void ( ^ ) ( PTRApiResponse * )) * callback * Parameters: callback Asynchronous block which will be returned along with server response regarding device registration. setPreferredLanguage: ¶ Sets preferred language for current user. This allows content to have relevant translation if available. If not, content is returned in default language. SDK will remember user’s preferred language until it’s set to another language or reset. - ( void ) setPreferredLanguage: ( NSString * _Nullable ) * languageCode * Parameters: languageCode ISO language code (eg. “en”, “jp”). Passing in nil will reset user preference to default. Warning This is stored on device only. Pointr Cloud will not know user’s preference. @warn This method may only be called when there is an active user session. Otherwise it will have no effect.
docs.title: PTRUserManagerInterface

@property ( nonatomic , readonly ) NSArray < NSString *> * portalNeighbours uniqueIdentifier ¶ uniqueIdentifier Unique identifier assigned by SDK @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) NSString * uniqueIdentifier Instance Methods ¶ initWithOriginalNodeId:location:neighbours:strPortalNeighbours: ¶ Alternative initialiser with string portal neighbours - ( instancetype ) initWithOriginalNodeId: ( long ) * originalNodeId * location :( PTRLocation * ) * location * neighbours :( NSArray < PTRGraphNodeNeighbour *> * ) * neighbours * strPortalNeighbours :( NSArray < NSString *> * ) * portalNeighbours * Parameters: neighbours have specific class (rather than the generic interface) portalNeighbours of type string rather than number Returns: A PTRGraphNode object initWithOriginalNodeId y:level:venueId:facilityId:neighbours:portalNeighbours: ¶ Default initialiser - ( instancetype ) initWithOriginalNodeId: ( long ) * originalNodeId * x :( float ) * x * y :( float ) * y * level :( int ) * level * venueId :( int ) * venueId * facilityId :( int ) * facilityId * neighbours :( NSArray < PTRGraphNodeNeighbour *> * ) * neighbours * portalNeighbours :( NSArray < NSNumber *> * ) * portalNeighbours * Parameters: neighbours have specific class (rather than the generic interface) Returns: A PTRGraphNode object isValid ¶ Checks if node has valid neighbours @warn Doesn’t check if nodes exist - ( BOOL ) isValid Returns: YES if this node has neighbours and they are valid, NO otherwise

docs.text: PTRPortalNode ¶ Inherits from PTRNodeInterface : NSObject Conforms to NSCoding NSCopying Declared in PTRPortalNode.h Overview ¶ Portal nodes in graph, used for navigating across levels usually (eg. lift) Properties ¶ endNode ¶ endNode Portal ends at this node @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) PTRPortalNodeChildNode * endNode isAccessible ¶ isAccessible YES if this portal is step-free, suitable for users with accessibility needs NO otherwise @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) BOOL isAccessible isComfortable ¶ isComfortable YES if this portal is suitable for large groups (eg. family with kids) NO otherwise @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) BOOL isComfortable isStartNode ¶ isStartNode Each portal node contains two nodes This flag determines which @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) BOOL isStartNode YES if this node represents its startnode NO if this node represents its endnode startNode ¶ startNode Portal starts from this node @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) PTRPortalNodeChildNode * startNode travelTime ¶ travelTime Travel time (of using this portal) in seconds @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) int travelTime type ¶ type Type of node (eg. lift, staircase) @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) PTRNodeType type Instance Methods ¶ addNeighbour: ¶ Unlike PTRGraphNode , this class allows adding neighbours post initialisation This is useful for performance Warning You can only add neighbours for endNode . docs.text: PTRPathDirection ¶ Inherits from NSObject Conforms to NSCoding NSCopying Declared in PTRPathDirection.h Overview ¶ Building block of turn by turn directions for path objects Properties ¶ angle ¶ angle Angle of turn, with respect to walking direction (in radians, valid only for turns) @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) float angle endNode ¶ endNode Where this direction should end Warning Might be nil for single node directions @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) PTRNodeInterface * endNode message ¶ message Human readable explanation of direction @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) NSString * message startNode ¶ startNode Where this direction should be applied @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) PTRNodeInterface * startNode type ¶ type Type enumeration of the path direction @property ( nonatomic , readonly ) PTRPathDirectionType type Instance Methods ¶ initBorderControlDirectionFrom ¶ Direction to pass through Border Control - ( instancetype ) initBorderControlDirectionFrom: ( PTRNodeInterface * ) * start * to :( PTRNodeInterface * ) * end * Parameters: start Starting point (node) end End point (node) initChangeFacilityDirectionFrom ¶ Direction to change facility between nodes - ( instancetype ) initChangeFacilityDirectionFrom: ( PTRNodeInterface * ) * start * to :( PTRNodeInterface * ) * end * Parameters: start Starting point (node). end End point (node). Returns: Path direction between specified nodes. initChangeLevelDirectionFrom ¶ Direction to change level between nodes - ( instancetype ) initChangeLevelDirectionFrom: ( PTRNodeInterface * ) * start * to :( PTRNodeInterface * ) * end * Parameters: start Starting point (node). end End point (node). Returns: Path direction between specified nodes. initSecurityDirectionFrom ¶ Direction to pass through Security - ( instancetype ) initSecurityDirectionFrom: ( PTRNodeInterface * ) * start * to :( PTRNodeInterface * ) * end * Parameters: start Starting point (node) end End point (node) initStraightDirectionFrom ¶ Direction to go straight between nodes - ( instancetype ) initStraightDirectionFrom: ( PTRNodeInterface * ) * start * to :( PTRNodeInterface * ) * end * Parameters: start Starting point (node). end End point (node). Returns: Path direction between the given nodes. initTurnDirectionAtNode:isLeft:withAngle: ¶ Direction to make a turn at given node. - ( instancetype ) initTurnDirectionAtNode: ( PTRNodeInterface * ) * node * isLeft :( BOOL ) * isLeft * withAngle :( float ) * angle * Parameters: node Next node to be arrived. isLeft Flag determining if its a left turn. angle Angle respective to travel path, in radians Returns: Path direction at the specified node. initTurnSlightDirectionAtNode:isLeft:withAngle: ¶ Direction to make a slight turn at given node and continue straight - ( instancetype ) initTurnSlightDirectionAtNode: ( PTRNodeInterface * ) * node * isLeft :( BOOL ) * isLeft * withAngle :( float ) * angle * Parameters: node Next node to be arrived. isLeft Flag determining if its a left turn. angle Angle respective to y-axis, in radians Returns: Path direction at the specified node. initWithType:andWithAngle: ¶ Represents a direction with direction type and angle . - ( instancetype ) initWithType: ( PTRPathDirectionType ) * type * andWithAngle :( float ) * angle * Parameters: type Represented path direction type . angle Angle value of turn Returns: Direction representing only type updateStartNodeTo: ¶ Updates start node. This method is used to reuse direction objects and be able to update their start nodes (e.g. as you progress on this path) Only sensible for continuous direction objects (such as ‘straight’ or ‘slight turn and straight’ types) - ( void ) updateStartNodeTo: ( PTRNodeInterface * ) * newStartNode * Parameters: newStartNode New start node for path

docs.text: Glossary ¶ 2FA ¶ Two Factor Authentication, a more advanced form of security that leverages a second device or point of entry to verify that a user is who they say they are. For instance you might have a key generator for your bank as a Second Security Factor for online banking transactions. AltBeacon ¶ Open Source implementation of “iBeacon” beacon proximity specification Android ¶ Mobile operating system of Google smartphone and tablets Android Studio ¶ Official IDE for Android code development. Angular Stairs ¶ an Angled Staircase accessible to SDK users API ¶ Application Programming Interface. In this context, used to describe online communication endpoints provided by Pointr Cloud or another server. Beacon ¶ Emitter device. In this context, means BLE sensor hardware. BLE ¶ Acronym for Bluetooth Low Energy. Also named Bluetooth 4.0 or Bluetooth Smart, low energy profile introduced, adopted and standardised by global Bluetooth community. Blue dot ¶ Depiction of user position on a map, using a blue dot icon Bluetooth ¶ Wireless radio technology, operating at frequencies between 2402 and 2480 MHz, or 2400 and 2483.5 MHz. Contemporary preference for ‘low bandwidth, low latency’ applications Bluetooth Low Energy ¶ Also named Bluetooth 4.0 or Bluetooth Smart, low energy profile introduced, adopted and standardised by global Bluetooth community. Bluetooth Smart ¶ Also named Bluetooth Low Energy or Bluetooth 4.0, low energy profile introduced, adopted and standardised by global Bluetooth community. Calibration ¶ In this context, depicts the initial process Pointr’s positioning engine goes through to improve accuracy and especially orientation. CMS ¶ Acronym for Content Management System. Eddystone ¶ Bluetooth Low Energy protocol, introduced by Google. Uses a different format from iBeacon/AltBeacon. Not widely adopted and somewhat abandoned by Google Graph ¶ Data model used on which pathfinding is based. Guru ¶ Pointr proprietary mobile app, used to configure beacon hardware. GPS ¶ Acronym for Global Positioning System. A very common positioning technology, using information from special satellites around the Earth, to work out a person or asset’s geographic position (typically in latitude and longitude units) Heading ¶ Synonym of ‘Orientation’ Host App ¶ Mobile application containing Pointr SDK iBeacon ¶ Proprietary Bluetooth Low Energy protocol, introduced by Apple. Beacons conforming to iBeacon have a set 16-byte UUID, and a 2-bytes each for a Major and Minor ID IDE ¶ Acronym for Integrated Development Environment, which is a piece of software that aids in Software Development iOS ¶ Mobile operating system of Apple smartphone and tablets. JSON ¶ Acronym for JavaScript Object Notation , it represents a textual file format consisting of curly brackets to indicate dictionary, square brackets to indicate array, commas to list items and double quotation marks to indicate values. Latitude ¶ A geographical coordinate, specifying North-South position of a point on the Earth’s surface. License Key ¶ In this context, a text key provided by Pointr to 3 rd party for unlocking SDK functionality. Without a valid license key, SDK will turn itself off. Longitude ¶ A geographical coordinate, specifying East-West position of a point on the Earth’s surface. Major ¶ 2 byte numeric value, advertised by beacon hardware, as part of iBeacon protocol. Map Widget ¶ UI component inside Pointr Mobile SDK that is used to display a map with typically a position pin and icons for points of interest. Minor ¶ 2 byte numeric value, advertised by beacon hardware, as part of iBeacon protocol. Node ¶ Building units of graph. Each node indicates a pathfinding point on a map. Orientation ¶ Device orientation means the direction with which a device is held. Pin orientation means the angle at which a position is facing. OS ¶ Operating System PathFinder Pointr SDK component that provides Pathfinding logic PC ¶ acronym for Pointr Cloud Poi Point of interest. In Pointr terminology, any item that can be searched for in a venue (eg. restaurant, exit, restroom) Pointr Cloud ¶ Pointr Backend, where you will find web dashboards for CMS, data analytics, marketing and administration as well as a RESTful API. POP ¶ Point of Presence, which is the name of Pointr’s WiFi and BLE sniffer hardware, typically used for data collection in venues. Portal ¶ Graph nodes that enable level or building change (eg. stairs, lift) Raster Map ¶ Map based on single graphic, typically JPG or PNG. REST ¶ Representational State Transfer. Conventional web/data transfer standard. In this context, used to describe characteristics of API requests etc (eg. talking to Pointr Cloud ). Tiled Map ¶ Map Tiles Map composed of many small tiles, in grid fashion, with different quality images at different resolutions. Tracking Mode ¶ Display mode for Map Widget. Available options are: free mode (no tracking), tracking mode (where map is locked to user pin and map stays static while position pin rotates) and rotational tracking mode (where map is locked to user pin and map rotates while pin stays fixed) Transparent Wall ¶ Special wall type to indicate to Pathfinder that a user should not be directed through a particular area, even if there is no literal wall. For instance, to avoid Pathfinding through a Garden etc. UI ¶ User Interface UUID ¶ Universally Unique Identifier. In this context, used to describe the main identifier of an advertisment from beacon hardware. Typically seen in iBeacon and AltBeacon beacon implementations WiFi ¶ Most commonly used wireless radio technology, such as for internet communication at homes and offices. X Coordinate ¶ Horizontal coordinate in a grid. In Pointr system, leftmost point has 0 and rightmost point has 1.0 value. Xcode ¶ Official IDE for iOS code development on Mac environments. Y Coordinate ¶ Vertical coordinate in a grid. In Pointr system, top point has 0 and bottom point has 1.0 value. Zoom Level ¶ Describes how much zoomed in / out the user is in. ‘Zoom out’ means user is zoomed out. ‘Zoom in’ mean user is zoomed in, seeing everything at larger scale. Zoom mid means the zooming scale between ‘Zoom out’ and ‘Zoom in’.

docs.text: Frequently Asked Questions ¶ Why didn’t I get an email when I used the “Can’t remember password” option? ¶ Check the following: You are attempting to access the correct domain. Your email is registered. If it persists, get in touch or contact your admin to resolve this issue. Why can’t see a Venue that I want to work on? ¶ If you cannot see a Venue in the dropdown menu, this might be because your account does not yet have appropriate access. Contact your admin to request access to the venue. Why can I not see any data on my graphs? ¶ Make sure that you selected the correct time interval where some data should have been collected. Make sure that the store is selected. Check if the Beacons or POP devices are working from the Settings and Configuration screens. Contact us if you are still having issues Why does the Heatmap/Simulation screen show Visitor Data on the map where they cannot go (e.g staff only areas, walls)? ¶ Ensure that the Beacon or POP Device have been appropriately placed on the map in the Map Designer screen, if this is applicable. I added a map and saved it, why is not yet visible to app Users? ¶ Make sure to publish the map after saving. Users can only see the map if it is published after saving. It might also take a few minutes to percolate to every user. How can I add a POI Layer type that is not one of the predefined options? ¶ Make sure that the POI Type you wish to add cannot already be added as one of the options in the drop-down list. Contact your admin. I selected POI Layer and click the green plus sign, nothing happens. What should I do? ¶ You should select one of the POI Type options that is below POI Layer in the dropdown menu. POI Layer itself is not a POI Layer type. I want to add a Path Layer but the add button does not appear. How do I add the Path Layer? ¶ Make sure that the Path Layer is selected and highlighted in red on the right menu. Why can’t I see Path/POI layer that I added previously? ¶ Make sure that there is an “Eye Symbol” in the box left of Path / POI layer option on the right menu. If there is not, click inside the box. If you can see the “Eye Symbol”, this means that the items are visible. If the “Eye Symbol” is there and you still cannot see what you added previously, this means that you must have exited the page before saving and publishing. Make sure to click Save to save your progress and click Publish to make it available to the users. Why can’t I see Shape options whilst adding a POI Layer? ¶ Zoom out and/or scroll up - The Shape options appear on the upper left corner of the Map.
docs.title: FAQ - Pointr Cloud

If you can see the “Eye Symbol”, this means that the items are visible. If the “Eye Symbol” is there and you still cannot see what you added previously, this means that you must have exited the page before saving and publishing. Make sure to click Save to save your progress and click Publish to make it available to the users.

docs.text: h4 { width: 100%; text-align: center; display: inline-block; } Technical Features ¶ What is included with my SDK? ¶ Typically, for the purposes of integration, we will share The SDK, as a Native Library File (​ .framework or ​ .embeddedframework on iOS, ​ .aar via Artifactory) Sample project SDK documentation Which platforms are supported? ¶ Pointr Mobile SDK supports iOS 7.0 and later Android v4.3 and later Which mobile phones are supported? ¶ Pointr Mobile SDK should support any official smartphone or tablet that can run iOS 7.0 and later Android v4.3 and later, but support is limited if device does not have the required sensors Does SDK have tablet support? ¶ Pointr SDK is designed to work on any device screen size, however the device will still need to have the required sensors to function​ correctly while using Pointr SDK. You may only have limited support and a reduced experience without the required dependencies Does SDK support landscape orientation? ¶ At this time of writing, SDK does not ​ support landscape orientation for positioning functionality. All other functionality work regardless of portrait / landscape orientation. Landscape orientation for positioning is in the roadmap. What happens if a phone doesn’t have Bluetooth on / support Bluetooth? ¶ Bluetooth is required for positioning to work. Without bluetooth, other SDK functionality (such as Poi search or indoor maps) will continue to work without position. What happens if a user does not authorise location permission? ¶ Location permission is required for SDK to calculate device’s position. Without location permission, other SDK functionality (such as Poi search or indoor maps) will continue to work without position. Does SDK work in hybrid applications? ¶ Pointr Mobile SDK is not actively tested for hybrid frameworks (eg. Mono or Apache Cordova) but in theory, as long as SDK can access native phone libraries (such as Bluetooth capabilities), it should continue to work. Does SDK work in the background? ¶ Pointr Mobile SDK can be configured to work in background and this is a nice feature (both for data collection but also for delightful features such as a notification when a user arrives at a venue or a zone). iOS and Android exhibit different behaviour in background and may show various OS limitations. For your specific use case, please discuss with us. Please note that background tracking needs to be enabled by 3 rd party and users need to opt-in. Pointr Mobile SDK cannot work in background without configuration or opt-in. Data / Internet Usage ¶ Does SDK work without internet? ¶ All main components of Pointr Mobile SDK , such as positioning or pathfinding, are designed to work 100% offline. Internet is only required for: Content update License validation (when SDK starts*) Push notifications Data upload** Once a license is validated, this result will be cached for a duration (a month or so) to avoid internet requirement upon each SDK start. ** Without internet, all data is cached on the device and uploaded as soon as device connects to internet. What happens when user loses internet connectivity? ¶ All main components of Pointr Mobile SDK , such as positioning or pathfinding, are designed to work 100% offline. Therefore, SDK continues to work as normal. Losing internet connectivity only impacts: Content update License validation (see note below) Push notifications Data upload (see note below) License Validation? License is validated on start up. Once a license is validated, this result will be cached for a duration (a month or so) to avoid internet requirement upon each SDK start. What happens to data upload when there is no connection? Without internet, all data is cached on the device and uploaded as soon as device connects to internet. What data gets collected? ¶ SDK uploads several types of data to Pointr Cloud (when it has internet). These include: Device position (coordinates and timestamp) SDK Analytics information (eg. number of searches carried out, number of pathfinding calculations) Crash logging (see note below) Beacon maintenance information (ie. reporting detected beacons’ battery and status) Propagating Crash Logging Internal crash logger of SDK passes the crash back to application. This ensures your Crash Loggers will continue to function as normal, or if there is no other crash logger, allow the application to crash as expected. What data does SDK store on the device? ¶ SDK will use device storage for improved performance and data preservation. Stored data include: Venue content (such as Poi’s, walls, graph) Outstanding network requests (please refer to ‘What data gets collected?’) SDK will erase outstanding network requests as soon as they are sent to server successfully. Venue content will not be reset unless explicitly erased via 3 rd party code. Does SDK store personally identifying information? ¶ SDK, by default, uses a unique device identifier, which identifies device for the host application only. This default identifier is only useful to detect that the same anonymous user is using the same host application again. It is not possible to identify who this user is nor to sell this identifier data to another application as it is useless outside the current host application. If requested, it is possible to add additional profile information to users (such as loyalty card number) along with Pointr internal unique device identifier. This allows 3 rd parties to identify their users via these additional meta data. This needs to be organised by the 3 rd party and SDK, on its own, cannot gather extra information as such. Can I stop data collection? ¶ When SDK is not started, no data is collected. Furthermore, 3 rd parties can stop any data upload from happening via disabling relevant flags in configuration file. Permissions Required from Users ¶ Do users opt-in? ¶ Various functionality, such as Bluetooth use, sensor use, background location, of SDK only work on an opt-in basis. These are restricted via configuration in the SDK but also, restricted by Apple and Google also. Which permissions are required? ¶ Pointr SDK needs Location authorisation (when needed and/or always) on iOS Remote notifications (optional) on iOS Coarse location on Android Push notifications (optional) on Android Notifications ¶ Can I disable push notifications? ¶ Push notifications only work if server (Apple or Google) generated tokens are passed back to Pointr Cloud , using the relevant ‘Push Manager’ methods in Pointr SDK . Therefore, push notifications can only be enabled by 3 rd parties. Once enabled, if a 3 rd party wants to disable push notifications, they can call to ‘unregister’ from push notifications via ‘Push Manager’ methods in Pointr SDK . Security ¶ Does Pointr SDK use HTTP or HTTPS? ¶ Pointr SDK uses HTTP or HTTPS based on 3 rd party configuration. Pointr advise HTTPS communication for all production environments. Testing ¶ Does SDK have debugging mode? ¶ Yes. Pointr SDK can be configured for Debugging or Release mode. Development mode enables information and verbose logging and unlock various debugging features. How can I test that the Pointr SDK is working successfully? ¶ There’s no better test than on-site with installed and configured beacons, however this may not always be achievable. To help with testing Pointr SDK supports debugging features tools such as: Using the Joystick , to mock user position on site Simulation files, to replay a recorded app experience (and more) In addition, we advise testing with a handful of beacons, configured as real site beacons, to simulate a real Bluetooth environment for testing. It makes good sense to verify with our SampleApp before you assume there is an issue. Dependencies ¶ Does SDK have framework dependencies? ¶ Yes. Pointr SDK needs the following OS dependencies: iOS ¶ CoreLocation.framework CoreBluetooth.framework CoreMotion.framework Foundation.framework SystemConfiguration.framework UIKit.framework AVFoundation.framework (optional, only if Augmented Reality or On-screen Translation are used) Android ¶ (feature) android.hardware.sensor.accelerometer (feature) android.hardware.sensor.compass (sdk) com.pointrlabs.core,com.qozix.tileview (service) com.google.android.gms.gcm.GcmReceiver (service) com.google.android.core.push.PointrGcmListenerService (service) com.google.android.core.push.PointrInstanceIDListenerService (service) com.pointrlabs.core.push.RegistrationIntentService Does SDK use 3 rd party / open source libraries? ¶ Yes, Pointr SDK makes minimal use of external libraries (to avoid potential compatibility or support issues). iOS ¶ Library License Reference Purpose ziparchive MIT (^) https://code.google.com/archive/p/ziparchive/ Extracting .zip files (for map tiles) DeviceUtil MIT (^) https://github.com/InderKumarRathore Recognising all iOS devices Reachability Special (free) https://github.com/tonymillion/Reachability Detecting device network connectivity Android ¶ Library License Reference Purpose TileView MIT (^) https://github.com/moagrius/TileView Displaying optimised map tiles

docs.text: Troubleshooting ¶ General issues ¶ SDK fails to start - “Invalid BaseConfiguration” ¶ You will not be able to run a Pointr SDK instane without a valid BaseConfiguration.json file Please ensure BaseConfiguration.json is added to bundle BaseConfiguration.json is a valid JSON (with no extra commas) BaseConfiguration.json contains an object with the key sdkConfiguration ​ with baseUrl ,​ uuidList ​and ​ beaconBrandName SDK is running but no map is shown ¶ Typically the SDK’s state is irrelevant of the content you should see. Generally we find that configuration issues are the problem. Please ensure Map Widget is added and it has a visible frame on the screen Facility is selected (refer to “Venue selection”) You have internet connection (if maps not bundled with app) Android issues ¶ Android SampleApp is missing .aar file ¶ Android SDK is served through Artifactory, if you find yourself having issues getting hold of the SDK, you can review the bundled Sample App Check the Sample App for examples of how to: Add Pointr’s build server as a Maven repository Add Pointr SDK file Specify username and API key for access iOS issues ¶ iOS is a terrible platform ¶ We’ll have to build up some iOS specific integration troubleshooting questions Tip You should get an android device? ;) Get in touch ¶ If you can’t find what you’re looking for then we need to update our docs! Get in touch with us and tell us about your issue at support@pointrlabs.com …For really technical issues ¶ If you have a technical issue, the we can help you much faster if you describe how we can recreate your problem and then share any logs or relevant information with us.
docs.title: Troubleshooting

docs.text: Tip This page is describes some common features new to If you’re looking for an in-depth description of changes for a specific Pointr platform, you can find the changelogs here: Android iOS Pointr Cloud New features added ¶ Drawable Interface and Drawing on the MapView ¶ Introducing Drawable interface, which can be implemented by any class that you wish to draw on the map, such as: Points Of Interest A Custom User Pin A drawn Path for wayfinding etc… Drawable has the following properties: Property Type Description identifier String Arbitrary unique identifier to recognise this Drawable centerPoint Point Normalised screen position where both x and y are within [0,1] interval: x: 0 y: 0 -> Top left x: 0.5 y: 0.5 -> Centre x: 0 y: 1 -> Bottom left x: 1 y: 1 -> Bottom right minimumZoomLevel Float Minimum (farthest out) zoom at which this Drawable can be viewed maximumZoomLevel Float Maximum (farthest in) zoom at which this Drawable can be viewed isRotatable Boolean Whether Drawable should rotate with Map isInteractive Boolean Whether Drawable allows interaction (eg. selection on Map) canBeHiddenWhenClashed Boolean Whether this Drawable can be hidden by other Drawable objects in case of clash (see note) canHideOthersWhenClashed Boolean Whether this Drawable can cause other Drawable objects to hide in case of clash (see note) Clash Priority Clash priority is currently arbitrary . In other words, it is not possible to specify which Drawable has higher drawing Priority than another. Drawables ¶ LineDrawable - used to represent any line that can be drawn on the Map, including a Path object. ( iOS Only ) RegionDrawable - used to represent a region to be drawn on the Map. DrawablePointView - a convenient that can be created for drawing arbitrary point objects onto the Map. Drawing on the MapView ¶ You can now draw anywhere on the map, and drawing on MapView has been simplified by adding functions addDrawable(Drawable d) and removeDrawable(Drawable d) . Below is an example of how you might carry this out: OBJECTIVE-C ... MapView map = new MapView (); map . delegate = self ; ... Drawable d1 = new Drawable ( identifier = @ “ building - entrance - sofa ” ) map . addDrawable ( d1 ); ... function View viewForDrawable :( Drawable d ) { if ( d . identifier == “ building - entrance - sofa ” ) { return View (); } ... } JAVA ... map = ( BasePointrMapView ) view . findViewById ( R . id . view_map ); ... map . setMapViewProvider ( this ); map . addListener ( this ); ... SimpleDrawable d1 = new SimpleDrawable (); d1 . setIdentifier ( d1 ); map . addDrawable ( d1 ); ... @Override public View viewForDrawable ( MapDrawable drawable ){ if ( drawable . getIdentifier (). equalsIgnoreCase ( "building-entrance-sofa" )){ return ...; } } Ensuring Drawables get drawn The MapView will not draw any items unless they have been added to the Container using these, or related methods. For each Drawable that is added to the MapView, a View Object will be requested from its Delegate Object. Drawing Poi’s on MapView ¶ Poi class now implements the Drawable ​interface. Therefore, a Poi object can now be added to MapView directly. To specify how a Poi is drawn, use the Drawable viewForDrawable ​ callback, as outlined above. Pointr SDK also supports ​ PoiView which is the default View class to display Poi’s on Map. Using PoiView has​ the additional benefit that the internal Clash Resolver recognise them and can cleverly hide/show label and/or icons. Please note Clash Resolver should be enabled (in configuration) for this to work. For any other custom View, the Clash Resolver treats the whole View as a whole rectangle (ie. it uses a rectangle boundary box). For PoiView, however, it treats a PoiView’s label and icon separately giving it further flexibility in display. Drawing Path on MapView ¶ Unlike Poi objects, a Path should be drawn as a line on the MapView . Therefore, Path conforms to LineDrawable interface which has its designated​ ​callback. This callback allows modifying the Path to be drawn with any shape and colour. MapView callbacks ¶ MapView now supports two new interfaces with new callbacks, summarised below: MapViewDataSource ¶ Info this list is neither exhaustive, nor final Callback Description viewForDrawable(Drawable) the actual View object for the specified Drawable that is to be drawn in an arbitrary place on the MapView layerForLineDrawable(Drawable) the Layer object for specified LineDrawable layerForRegionDrawable(Drawable) Layer object for specified Region Drawable MapViewDelegate ¶ Info this list is neither exhaustive, nor final Callback Description onDrawablePointViewTouched(DrawablePointView) Called upon detecting touch on a DrawablePointView Note : Drawable needs isInteractive​ flag set to true for this callback to work onMapLevelChangedTo(int) Called when map’s current level is changed to another level onMapRotationModeChangedTo(MapMode) Called when map’s current map mode is changed to another mode MapView and Container hierarchy ¶ In this version, we have moved a lot of logic embedded inside the MapView to outside containers. This is to allow more flexibility and control. If you make no changes to this code, the default Pointr Map experience is provided, however, you can customise the whole UI logic here, try it out in your SampleApp on iOS ¶ Class Purpose PTRContainerVC Extends PTRContainerBaseVC. Allows customising default behaviour by overriding methods. PTRContainerBaseVC Contains default Map UX code, to coordinate MapView interactions. PTRMapView Standalone Map view, pulling data directly from the SDK as they become available and fully controllable via properties. Doesn’t contain much UX logic, controlled externally from the Container VC’s. PTRMapModeView Button to control Map Mode, provided as a standalone widget Note:​ This button doesn’t control the Map object. Instead, Container VC listens for this View’s callbacks to control Map accordingly. PTRSearchView Button that shows search input and takes over its parent frame when search is activated. on Android ¶ Class Purpose PointrMapActivity Sample Activity showing how to start Pointr SDK and how to start displaying the container Fragment ContainerFragment Fragment that displays and coordinates PointrMapView as well as additional UI widgets such as search input and MapModeView PointrMapView Standalone Map view, pulling data directly from the SDK as they become available and fully controllable via properties. Doesn’t contain much UX logic, controlled externally from PointrMapContainerFragment. MapModeView Button to control Map Mode, provided as a standalone widget Note:​ This button doesn’t control the Map object. Instead, Container Fragment listens for this View’s callbacks to control Map accordingly. Changes to POIs ¶ Poi Types ¶ There are two types of Poi objects: Single or Grouped . Single Pois are represented by ​ Poi class, which represents a single Point Of Interest object at the venue (eg. a specific entrance door, a specific cafe, a specific toilet). Grouped Pois are represented by PoiGroup ​ class,​ which represent a collection of somehow related Points of Interest (eg. all toilets, all the coffee shops, or all entrances of a venue). PoiContainer revision ¶ In this version, we are introducing PoiContainer ​ which handle both Single and Grouped Poi’s. All of PoiManager ‘s search, or getter methods, will return a PoiContainer which may contain zero, one, or more Pois. If you want to access all Poi​ ’s in a ​ PoiContainer ​ object, call ​ PoiContainer.getPoiList() If you want to access all​ PoiGroup ’s​ in a ​ PoiContainer ​object, call PoiContainer.getPoiGroupList() Example ¶ Imagine a venue has 10 toilets mapped OBJECTIVE-C ... // This search will return a PoiContainer containing all Poi’s matching “toilet” self . resultContainer = [ poiManager searchPoi : "toilet" ]; // This will return a list of all toilet Poi’s self . searchedPois = [ self . resultContainer getPoiList ]; // This will return a single PoiGroup object representing the toilets Poi’s altogether. self . searchedPois = [ self . resultContainer getPoiGroupList ]; ... JAVA ... // This search will return a PoiContainer containing all Poi’s matching “toilet” PoiContainer container1 = PoiManager . search ( “ toilet ” ); // This will return a list of all toilet Poi’s List < Poi > toilets = container1 . getPoiList (); // This will return a single PoiGroup object representing the toilets Poi’s altogether. List < PoiGroup > toiletGroups = container1 . getPoiGroupList (); ... In this example, “toilet” might be a title, description or keyword. With a specific Toilet Poi , I can ask the PathManager to navigate to a specific Poi . With the toiletGroups PoiGroup , I can ask the PathManager to navigate to any nearest toilet. Use Case Poi or PoiGroup Explanation Display some Poi’s on map Poi Map should show all Poi objects. For example, if there are 10 toilets at the venue, users will expect to see each one on the map separately. Show search results Varies If you want to list all items separately (eg. to show where each toilet is), you should use Poi If you want to show a grouped result (eg. to group all toilets into one entry in the search result list), you should use PoiGroup Navigate to a specific Poi Poi PathManager needs to know exact Poi that you want to navigate to. Navigate to nearest Poi within a group. PoiGroup PathManager needs to know a group of Poi’s from which to select the closest. Changes ¶ Route Summary Screen (Optional) ¶ We have introduced a “Route Summary Screen” that shows the User a summary of their plotted route before starting a pathfinding session. This is very useful for the User, especially in the case where elevators, security checkpoints, or some other special case has to be communicated and you want to avoid confusion. On iOS, this functionality is enabled by default, if you use the default Navigation Footer’s Route functionality. Alternatively, it can be directly accessed (via PTRRouteVC ). On Android, this is added in source code in BasePointrMapActivity. (Android) RouteScreenFragment (iOS) PTRRouteVC Get in touch Don’t forget! If you can’t still find what you’re looking for and you need some help, you can always get in touch
docs.title: Pointr Change Log

docs.text: Overview ¶ Here you’ll find detailed notes on the changes in the newest release of Pointr SDK for Android BaseContainerFragment ¶ This Fragment was previously embedded inside the SDK as BasePointrMapFragment. As of this version, we distribute it with the sample application to allow 3 rd parties full flexibility on map experience and design. To get setup, ​ clean old source and add new provided sample source code to your application. Previous New IkeaMapFragment (none) BasePointrMapFragment (Read Only) BaseContainerFragment (none) ContainerFragment (none) IkeaContainer Pointr.with ¶ A slight change to initialisation of the library - you should now start by specifying the desired logger level. Previous New Pointr. with (Context applicationContext, String licenceKey) Pointr. with (Context applicationContext, String licenceKey, int loggerLevel) Whitelisting for battery optimisations (Optional) ¶ This is only relevent on some devices, but if available, Pointr SDK can request user to “ Whitelist ” the app to enable it to run longer in background and not be disrupted by the OS. (Some Android versions may prompt the user to optimise for battery by restraining certain apps. Whitelisting prevents app to be in this list) Relevant code to address this can be found in ​the BasePointrMapActivity . Welcome / Goodbye notifications (Optional) ¶ This SDK packs our latest Bluetooth engine, which shows “Welcome” - “Goodbye” messages to user upon enter / exit to a Pointr-enabled venue. This is an optional feature that can be turned off completely. Further details will be shared with upcoming release. We switched to Firebase! ¶ Pointr SDK now uses Firebase for push notifications. To enable the Firebase functionality, the supplied google-services.json contents should be maintained. If this file is not included or becomes incorrect, Pointr SDK will continue to work regardless, but push notifications will not work as Firebase is not configured correctly. Plog ¶ Pointr now uses its internal logging mechanism named ​ Plog .​ These logs can be controlled via a logger level, as well as logcat controls. Previous New Log.v(TAG, message) Plog.v(message) Log.d(TAG, message) Plog.d(message) Log.i(TAG, message) Plog.i(message) Log.w(TAG, message) Plog.w(message) Log.e(TAG, message) Plog.e(message) Drawing Poi and Path ¶ SDK introduces two new methods, via MapViewProvider interface. This replaces previous binding method for Poi drawing and second method allows Path drawing too. Also note that the User Pin is also drawn using these methods now too. Previous New IKEAMapFragment: View onPoiBind (POI poi) BaseContainerFragment: DrawablePointView viewForDrawable (Drawable) BaseContainerFragment: DrawablePath lineViewForDrawable (Drawable) MapView.Listener methods ¶ In this version, most listener / events classes are collated into MapView.Listener for simplicity. Previous New onDrawablePointViewTouched (BasePointrMapView, DrawablePointView) OnVisibleMapLevelChangedListener. onVisibleLevelChanged (int) onMapLevelChangedTo (BasePointrMapView, int) onMapModeChangedTo (BasePointrMapView, MapMode) MapGestureListener. onSingleTap (MotionEvent) didReceiveSingleFingerTap (BasePointrMapView, MotionEvent) didReceiveDoubleFingerTap (BasePointrMapView, MotionEvent) Further developer notes ¶ updateMapViewBasedOnPosition ¶ This method needs to be implemented with the same logic as the sample code. At each position update, if the pin needs to be shown on map, it draws the pin on map with the call to updateUserPin(). It also calls the showPositionOnTheMapIfFirstOne() method, which as the name suggests, scrolls to user position if it is the first position of the user. This call and the method can be discarded according to implementation preference. onPositionIsFading & onPositionIsLost These callbacks need to be implemented if the implementation wants the user pin to fade and disappear according to a certain threshold based on the last valid position update updateUserPin ¶ This method is called from the updateMapViewBasedOnPosition, to update the user pin. The implementation of this method needs to stay as seen in the sample code. This method handles the operations regarding drawing the pin, which involves checking user position, user level, and the presence of drawableUserPin, and then draws the pin or hides it accordingly. If it the drawable of the pin view is not present, it creates the pin view with the method createPinView(). After creation of the pin view it calls the adjustUserPinView() method to adjust the pin drawable properties such as its orientation, accuracy and rotation. viewForDrawable ¶ This method is to create a view according to the drawable given to it as an argument. Any kind of drawable can be provided here, and the view will be created with that drawable. This gives the implementer an option to implement the view of pois, user pin and destination with custom drawables. lineForDrawable ¶ This method is creates the path object. Inside, it creates a CompositePathView.DrawablePath object, which needs to have a Paint object, and an android.graphics.Path object. These two objects can be configured as per the implementers choices, as long as they are fed to the DrawablePath object to be returned by the method. This method uses helpers such as calculatePathArrayForLevel, getLocationArrayFromNodes, calculatePathArray, which needs to stay as seen in the sample code, and is not open for alterations. onDrawablePointViewTouched ¶ This callback is triggered when a poi is clicked by the user, giving BasePointrMapView, and DrawablePointView as arguments. The BasePointrMapView signifies the map that the user has clicked on, this is needed since now the Pointr engine supports more than one map being shown on the screen. The DrawablePointView is the drawable that the user has clicked on. onMapLevelChangedTo ¶ This callback is triggered when the visible map level is changed. It gives the mapView object of the current map that has its level changed and the level that it has changed to. In order to optimise the map download the implementer can choose to prioritise the level user is viewing while downloading maps by adding the following line: notifyDataManagerOfLevelChange(level) . Also the code regarding level picker is present to highlight the visible level on level picker, if the level picker is not used, it is not necessary. The call to updatePoisInMap() is mandatory. If the implementer wants to make use of the store layout the call to adjustLevelForStoreLayout needs to be implemented. onMapModeChangedTo ¶ This callback is triggered when the map mode is changed. Eg. from ‘ Free ’ to ‘ Rotational Tracking ’. It handles the changes to the map mode, and then calls the method doModeChangeEventsWithMapMode, which can be overridden, however it is not advised as it may disrupt the architecture behind the map mode changes. didReceiveDoubleFingerTap ¶ This callback is triggered when the map detects two consecutive finger taps. It can be overridden to behave as the implementer pleases. onLocatorClicked ¶ This method locates the user pin when clicked. If the implementer does not wish to use the locator button, it does not need to be implemented userDidTapOnMapModeView This method is used to implement the architecture behind the map mode button. If the implementer does not wish to use the map mode button, it does not need to be implemented. Getting in touch Don’t forget - if you can’t still find what you’re looking for and you need some help, you can always for get in touch
docs.title: Android 5x Upgrade Guide Log

docs.text: Here you’ll find detailed notes on the changes in the newest release of Pointr SDK for Android
docs.title: Overview

docs.text: This Fragment was previously embedded inside the SDK as BasePointrMapFragment. As of this version, we distribute it with the sample application to allow 3 rd parties full flexibility on map experience and design. To get setup, ​ clean old source and add new provided sample source code to your application. Previous New IkeaMapFragment (none) BasePointrMapFragment (Read Only) BaseContainerFragment (none) ContainerFragment (none) IkeaContainer
docs.title: BaseContainerFragment

docs.text: A slight change to initialisation of the library - you should now start by specifying the desired logger level. Previous New Pointr. with (Context applicationContext, String licenceKey) Pointr. with (Context applicationContext, String licenceKey, int loggerLevel)
docs.title: Pointr.with

docs.text: This is only relevent on some devices, but if available, Pointr SDK can request user to “ Whitelist ” the app to enable it to run longer in background and not be disrupted by the OS. (Some Android versions may prompt the user to optimise for battery by restraining certain apps. Whitelisting prevents app to be in this list) Relevant code to address this can be found in ​the BasePointrMapActivity .
docs.title: Whitelisting for battery optimisations (Optional)

docs.text: This SDK packs our latest Bluetooth engine, which shows “Welcome” - “Goodbye” messages to user upon enter / exit to a Pointr-enabled venue. This is an optional feature that can be turned off completely. Further details will be shared with upcoming release.
docs.title: Welcome / Goodbye notifications (Optional)

docs.text: Pointr SDK now uses Firebase for push notifications. To enable the Firebase functionality, the supplied google-services.json contents should be maintained. If this file is not included or becomes incorrect, Pointr SDK will continue to work regardless, but push notifications will not work as Firebase is not configured correctly.
docs.title: We switched to Firebase!

docs.text: Pointr now uses its internal logging mechanism named ​ Plog .​ These logs can be controlled via a logger level, as well as logcat controls. Previous New Log.v(TAG, message) Plog.v(message) Log.d(TAG, message) Plog.d(message) Log.i(TAG, message) Plog.i(message) Log.w(TAG, message) Plog.w(message) Log.e(TAG, message) Plog.e(message)
docs.title: Plog

docs.text: SDK introduces two new methods, via MapViewProvider interface. This replaces previous binding method for Poi drawing and second method allows Path drawing too. Also note that the User Pin is also drawn using these methods now too. Previous New IKEAMapFragment: View onPoiBind (POI poi) BaseContainerFragment: DrawablePointView viewForDrawable (Drawable) BaseContainerFragment: DrawablePath lineViewForDrawable (Drawable)
docs.title: Drawing Poi and Path

docs.text: In this version, most listener / events classes are collated into MapView.Listener for simplicity. Previous New onDrawablePointViewTouched (BasePointrMapView, DrawablePointView) OnVisibleMapLevelChangedListener. onVisibleLevelChanged (int) onMapLevelChangedTo (BasePointrMapView, int) onMapModeChangedTo (BasePointrMapView, MapMode) MapGestureListener. onSingleTap (MotionEvent) didReceiveSingleFingerTap (BasePointrMapView, MotionEvent) didReceiveDoubleFingerTap (BasePointrMapView, MotionEvent)
docs.title: MapView.Listener methods

docs.text: This method needs to be implemented with the same logic as the sample code. At each position update, if the pin needs to be shown on map, it draws the pin on map with the call to updateUserPin(). It also calls the showPositionOnTheMapIfFirstOne() method, which as the name suggests, scrolls to user position if it is the first position of the user. This call and the method can be discarded according to implementation preference. onPositionIsFading & onPositionIsLost These callbacks need to be implemented if the implementation wants the user pin to fade and disappear according to a certain threshold based on the last valid position update
docs.title: updateMapViewBasedOnPosition

docs.text: This method is called from the updateMapViewBasedOnPosition, to update the user pin. The implementation of this method needs to stay as seen in the sample code. This method handles the operations regarding drawing the pin, which involves checking user position, user level, and the presence of drawableUserPin, and then draws the pin or hides it accordingly. If it the drawable of the pin view is not present, it creates the pin view with the method createPinView(). After creation of the pin view it calls the adjustUserPinView() method to adjust the pin drawable properties such as its orientation, accuracy and rotation.
docs.title: updateUserPin

docs.text: This method is to create a view according to the drawable given to it as an argument. Any kind of drawable can be provided here, and the view will be created with that drawable. This gives the implementer an option to implement the view of pois, user pin and destination with custom drawables.
docs.title: viewForDrawable

docs.text: This method is creates the path object. Inside, it creates a CompositePathView.DrawablePath object, which needs to have a Paint object, and an android.graphics.Path object. These two objects can be configured as per the implementers choices, as long as they are fed to the DrawablePath object to be returned by the method. This method uses helpers such as calculatePathArrayForLevel, getLocationArrayFromNodes, calculatePathArray, which needs to stay as seen in the sample code, and is not open for alterations.
docs.title: lineForDrawable

docs.text: This callback is triggered when a poi is clicked by the user, giving BasePointrMapView, and DrawablePointView as arguments. The BasePointrMapView signifies the map that the user has clicked on, this is needed since now the Pointr engine supports more than one map being shown on the screen. The DrawablePointView is the drawable that the user has clicked on.
docs.title: onDrawablePointViewTouched

docs.text: This callback is triggered when the visible map level is changed. It gives the mapView object of the current map that has its level changed and the level that it has changed to. In order to optimise the map download the implementer can choose to prioritise the level user is viewing while downloading maps by adding the following line: notifyDataManagerOfLevelChange(level) . Also the code regarding level picker is present to highlight the visible level on level picker, if the level picker is not used, it is not necessary. The call to updatePoisInMap() is mandatory. If the implementer wants to make use of the store layout the call to adjustLevelForStoreLayout needs to be implemented.
docs.title: onMapLevelChangedTo

docs.text: This callback is triggered when the map mode is changed. Eg. from ‘ Free ’ to ‘ Rotational Tracking ’. It handles the changes to the map mode, and then calls the method doModeChangeEventsWithMapMode, which can be overridden, however it is not advised as it may disrupt the architecture behind the map mode changes.
docs.title: onMapModeChangedTo

docs.text: This callback is triggered when the map detects two consecutive finger taps. It can be overridden to behave as the implementer pleases.
docs.title: didReceiveDoubleFingerTap

docs.text: This method locates the user pin when clicked. If the implementer does not wish to use the locator button, it does not need to be implemented userDidTapOnMapModeView This method is used to implement the architecture behind the map mode button. If the implementer does not wish to use the map mode button, it does not need to be implemented. Getting in touch Don’t forget - if you can’t still find what you’re looking for and you need some help, you can always for get in touch
docs.title: onLocatorClicked

docs.text: Overview ¶ Here you’ll find detailed notes on the changes in the newest release of Pointr SDK for iOS SampleApp UI hierarchy change ¶ In the previous sample project, map was added directly to the main view controller and its view ( self.view ). In this release, we provide a multi-tab prototype, and to demonstrate the adding of the MapView to a frame smaller than full-screen, we created a containerView in Main.storyboard , where we add the MapView . In your project, you can either Create ​your own containerView to contain the map or Assign containerView = self.view ​ to make MapView fill the screen that is displayed Be careful If you miss this step and fail to add the MapView , A blank screen will show (as the MapView is not present in the View Hierarchy) Target version ¶ As of this version, Pointr SDK has removed support for iOS 7, and now minimally supports iOS 8.0 and up Previous New Min target version: 7.0 Min target version: 8.0 Bitcode support ¶ This version does not support Bitcode generation. PointrMode ¶ PointrMode is changed to a Class. Previous New PointrModeProd [PointrReleaseMode mode] PointrModeDebug [PointrDebugMode mode] Joystick for testing ¶ Pointr iOS SDK now also supports use of a joystick to manually position yourself on the map. As with Android, this is intended to be a debug feature - not something that you will expose to your Users. To activate the Joystick, set mapView.shouldShowJoyStick to YES . To start off the mocked Joystick positioning, you need to hit one of the UP / DOWN / RR / RL buttons first. Info Note, on iOS when Joystick is enabled, unlike Android, Bluetooth reading is disabled to avoid conflicting the two positions. Previous New PTRMapView.shouldShowJoyStick Libraries to include in project ¶ You may refer to provided sample project also. Accelerate.framework AudioToolbox.framework SystemConfiguration.framework AVFoundation.framework GLKit.framework AVKit.framework CoreBluetooth.framework CoreLocation.framework CoreMotion.framework Pointr.framework libsqlite3.tbd libstdc++.tbd libz.tbd libcurl.a (can be found in Pointr.embededframework file) PTRMapView methods ¶ Previous New PTRMapView. startPathfinding Deprecated Use PathManager. startPathfinding instead PTRMapViewDataSource methods ¶ PTRAnnotationView is now deprecated. Rather than annotations, Pointr SDK now uses Drawable interface (as described above in the document). Drawables represent any item that could be drawn on the Map. Line drawing is also exposed to allow you full customisation of Path drawing. Previous New (PTRAnnotationView *)mapView:viewForAnnotation: (PTRDrawablePointView)mapView:viewForDrawable: (none) (CAShapeLayer) mapView:layerForRegionDrawable PTRMapViewDelegate methods ¶ Previous New (void)mapView:onPoiViewTouched: (void)mapView:onDrawablePointViewTouched: (void)mapView:onMapLevelChangedTo: Same (void)mapView:onMapRotationModeChangedTo: Same (void)mapView:didReceiveSingleFingerTap: Same (void)mapView:didZoomToLevel: Same (void)mapView:onPathfindingStarted: Deprecated : Use PathManagerDelegate callbacks instead (void)mapView:onUserCancelledPathfinding: Deprecated : Use PathManagerDelegate callbacks instead (void)mapView:onUserHasArrivedAtDestination: Deprecated : Use PathManagerDelegate callbacks instead (void)mapViewUserDidHideFooterView Deprecated : Footer View is now accessed via the Container class (PTRPathManagerSuggestionCallback)mapViewWillAskUserForSmartSuggestionCallback: Deprecated : This functionality is not supported in this version (none) (void)mapView:didInitializeSuccessfully: (none) (void)mapView:onLoadingStateChangedTo: (none) (void)mapView:onScreenRectChanged: PTRMapLoadingState ¶ PTRMapView now has a property to specify its current loading state, which can be any one of the following states: PTRMapLoadingStateOff PTRMapLoadingStateLoading PTRMapLoadingStateReady PTRMapLoadingStateError Previous New (none) PTRMapView.loadingState Further Development Notes ¶ Shrinking userPinView ¶ Shrinking userPinView for mapViews zoom level should be done in ContainerView if this is desired OBJECTIVE-C //can be used if smaller userpin when map zoomed out - ( void ) mapView: ( PTRMapView * ) mapView didZoomToLevel: ( float ) zoomLevel { dispatch_async ( dispatch_get_main_queue (), ^ { //Change size of userpin in terms of zoom level [ self shrinkUserPinView ]; }); } MapModes ¶ MapModes are now totally controlled by your in the ContainerBaseVC , so if the MapView level is changed by user (e.g. with a level selector view) and current position is on another level mode should be changed to free (otherwise map will zoom to user position for tracking mode). For example, the following should be in your MapView : onMapLevelChangedTo : delegate OBJECTIVE-C ... if ( level != _mapView . currentLocation . location . level ) { dispatch_async ( dispatch_get_main_queue (), ^ { [ _mapModeView setCurrentMapMode : PTRMapModeFree ]; [ mapView setCurrentMapMode : PTRMapModeFree ]; }); } ... IKEA has a store layout added from PointrCloud and this prevents user to see blue empty areas in the screen to enable this feature in every level the following should also be added to your MapView : onMapLevelChangedTo : delegate OBJECTIVE-C dispatch_async ( dispatch_get_main_queue (), ^ { //if there is a display area for this facility and level zoom to its center for not showing the other empty places id < PTRRegionDrawable > storeLayout = [ Pointr . sharedInstance . getPoiManager getStoreLayoutPoiForLevel : mapView . currentLevel forFacility : mapView . currentFacility ]; if ( storeLayout != nil && storeLayout . regionArray != nil ) { CGRect layoutLimits = [ self storeLayoutRectangleFromRegionArray : storeLayout . regionArray ]; mapView . layoutLimits = layoutLimits ; CGFloat zoom = mapView . minimumZoomScale + 0.01 ; CGPoint zoomPosition = storeLayout . centerPoint ; [ mapView zoomViewToX : zoomPosition . x andY : zoomPosition . y withZoomLevel : zoom ]; } [ self drawPoisInMapView : mapView ]; }); Info Zooming logic is added in the above to be sure the Map is not below the update minimum (void)mapView:(PTRMapView *)mapView onPoiViewTouched:(PTRPoi *) method has been changed to (void)mapView:(PTRMapView *)mapView onDrawablePointViewTouched:(PTRDrawablePointView *)drawablePointView Poi selection and view enlarging from tap will be made in container from now on please check inside new method mapView : onDrawablePointViewTouched : When map mode is changed mapView : onMapRotationModeChangedTo : callback is fired and from now on every change due to mode change will be made on container please check doModeChangeEventsWithMapMode:(PTRMapMode)mapMode function inside the mapView : onMapRotationModeChangedTo : delegate mapView : didReceiveSingleFingerTap : method is fired when a touch on mapView happened (if a touch on drawablePointView happens this callback is not fired) deselecting drawablePointView and containerState change should be done in this callback (see deselectDrawablePointView: and handleSingleTapOnMapview: methods in didReceiveSingleFingerTap: ) The new callback mapView : didInitializeSuccessfully : has been added to MapView and can be used to orchestrate events that should be carried out directly after MapView initialization The new callback mapView : onScreenRectChanged : is added to mapView to redraw pois on MapView . Info The Screen Rect can also be changed at initialization of the MapView , and on level changes if mapSizes are not same at levels Delegates ¶ PTRPoiManagerDelegate Methods ¶ PoiManager does nothing by itself from now on these should be done in Container using delegate methods onPoiManagerSelectedPoi: method can be used for enlarging and shrinking views onPoiManagerCurrentPoisUpdated: method should be used for re drawing pois in MapView onPoiManagerEnterTrigger: method can be used for trigger handling PTRSearchViewDelegate Method ¶ searchViewStartedPathFinding gets called when start call comes from searchView no method [self.mapView startPathfinding] can be used for starting the Pathfinding experience, however you should use [[[ Pointr sharedInstance ] getPathManager startPathfinding ]; PTRPositionManagerDelegate Methods ¶ onPositionManagerPositionIsFading and onPositionManagerPositionIsLost should be used if any change in view will be done onPositionManagerCalculatedLocation: is a replace for onPositionManagerCalculatedPosition: for MapView to respond those position changes this calculated location should be passed to mapView and do events with this position (please check updateMapView: basedOnCalculatedLocation: function in container) onPositionManagerDetectedPositionLevelChange: should be used if level change will be made if positions level change PTRPathManagerDelegate Methods ¶ onPathManagerPathCalculationAborted: will be used for events to do after path is aborted onPathManagerHasArrivedAtDestination: can be used for events to do after path is completed too (eg. show a arrival alert) onPathManagerHasCalculatedPath: should pass path to mapView (please see changePathWithPath : inMapView : method in Container. All turning and destination icons must be added from the Container onPathManagerPathCalculationFailedWithErrorMessage: should be used for resetting path in mapView PTRMapManagerDelegate Method ¶ this is used for updating the MapView after new data is received. onMapManagerMapUpdatedForVenue:(int)venueId facility:(int)facilityId level:(int)level mapType:(PTRDataType)mapType dataFromOnline:(BOOL)isOnlineData Getting in touch Don’t forget - if you can’t still find what you’re looking for and you need some help, you can always for get in touch
